Amendments--2013 (Adj. Sess.). Inserted "county" preceding "clerk".

§ 2602j. Court hearing and judgment.

  1. , (b) [Repealed.]
    1. issue a judgment, which shall supersede any certificate of election previously issued;
    2. send a certified copy of the judgment to the Secretary of State; and
    3. return to the county clerk any ballots containing questionable votes and defective ballots that had been forwarded to the court.

(c) Candidates and their attorneys shall be given the opportunity to present evidence to the court relating to the conduct of the recount, how to count questionable votes, and the marking of any ballot as defective in accordance with section 2547 or subsection 2587(d) of this title.

(d) On the day of the hearing, the town clerk of any town subject to the recount shall be available in person or by telephone to answer any questions regarding the town's election.

(e) If the court determines that any violations of recount procedures have occurred and that they may have affected the outcome of the recount, a new recount shall be ordered.

(f) After such hearings or arguments as may be indicated under the circumstances and after it has made a final decision on any questionable votes or defective ballots, the Superior Court, within five working days, shall:

Added 1985, No. 148 (Adj. Sess.), § 5; amended 2013, No. 161 (Adj. Sess.), § 42; 2017, No. 50, § 1.

History

Amendments--2017. Section amended generally.

Amendments--2013 (Adj. Sess.). Subsecs. (a) and (b): Inserted "county" preceding "clerk" throughout.

§ 2602k. Recount ties.

    1. If a recount of a primary election results in a tie, the provisions of subsection 2369(b) of this title shall apply. (a) (1) If a recount of a primary election results in a tie, the provisions of subsection 2369(b) of this title shall apply.
    2. If a recount of a public question results in a tie, a runoff election shall not be held, and the question shall be certified not to have passed.
    3. If a recount of a general election results in a tie, the provisions of this section shall apply, and the court shall order a runoff election to be held, within three weeks of the recount, on a date set by the court.
  2. The only candidates who shall appear on the ballot at the runoff election shall be those who tied in the previous election.
  3. The runoff election shall be considered a separate election for the purpose of voter registration under chapter 43 of this title.
  4. [Repealed.]
  5. Warnings for a runoff election shall be posted as required by subchapter 5 of this chapter, except that the warnings shall be posted not less than 10 days before the runoff election.
  6. The conduct of a runoff election shall be as provided in this chapter for general elections.

Added 1985, No. 148 (Adj. Sess.), § 5; amended 2013, No. 161 (Adj. Sess.), § 42; 2017, No. 50, § 1; 2019, No. 67, § 17.

History

Amendments--2019. Subsec. (a): Amended generally.

Subsec. (d): Repealed.

Amendments--2017. Section amended generally.

Amendments--2013 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (b): Substituted "The respective town clerks or their designees" for "The state police" at the beginning of the third sentence.

§ 2602 l. Repealed. 2013, No. 161 (Adj. Sess.), § 43.

History

Former § 2602l. Former § 2602l, relating to recounts using voting machines, was derived from 1985, No. 148 (Adj. Sess.), § 5 and amended by 2003, No. 59, § 41 and 2009, No. 40, § 4.

§ 2602m. Storage and return of election materials.

    1. After the recount, the county clerk shall store the sealed containers and any other recount materials in the county clerk's vault until returned to the towns. (a) (1) After the recount, the county clerk shall store the sealed containers and any other recount materials in the county clerk's vault until returned to the towns.
    2. The county clerk shall release all containers to the respective town clerks after issuance of the court's judgment, together with a copy of the judgment.
    3. The respective town clerks or their designees shall transport the containers to the towns from which they came.
  2. Upon receiving from the court any ballots containing questionable votes and defective ballots, the county clerk shall keep them in a sealed container for a period of two years.

Added 2017, No. 50, § 1.

§ 2603. Contest of elections.

  1. The result of an election for any office, other than for the General Assembly, or public question may be contested by any legal voter entitled to vote on the office or public question to be contested.
  2. A contest is initiated by filing a complaint with a Superior Court alleging:
    1. that errors were committed in the conduct of the election or in count or return of votes, sufficient to change the ultimate result;
    2. that there was fraud in the electoral process, sufficient to change the ultimate result; or
    3. that for any other reason, the result of the election is not valid.
  3. The complaint shall be filed within 15 days after the election in question, or if there is a recount, within 10 days after the court issues its judgment on the recount. In the case of candidates for State or congressional office, for a presidential election, or for a statewide public question, the complaint shall be filed with the Civil Division of the Superior Court, Washington County. In the case of any other candidate or public question, the complaint shall be filed with the Superior Court in any county in which votes were cast for the office or question being challenged.
  4. The Vermont Rules of Civil Procedure shall apply to contests of elections, except that such cases shall be placed upon a special calendar, and hearings shall be scheduled on a priority basis, as public policy demands that such questions be resolved promptly.
  5. After hearing, the court shall issue findings of fact and a judgment, which shall supersede any certificate of election previously issued. If the court finds just cause, the court shall grant appropriate relief, which may include ordering a recount, or ordering a new election. If during the hearing the court receives credible evidence of criminal conduct, the court shall order a transcript of all or part of the testimony to be forwarded to the proper State's Attorney. If a new election is ordered, the court shall set a date for it, after consulting with the Secretary of State; in ordering a new election, the court shall have authority to issue appropriate orders, either to provide for special cases not covered by law, or to supersede provisions of law that may conflict with the needs of the particular situation.
  6. The court shall send a certified copy of its findings of fact and judgment to the Secretary of State.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1979, No. 200 (Adj. Sess.), §§ 94, 95; 1981, No. 239 (Adj. Sess.), § 19; 1985, No. 148 (Adj. Sess.), § 6; 1985, No. 196 (Adj. Sess.), § 15; 2009, No. 154 (Adj. Sess.), § 141.

History

2018. In subsec. (e), in the second sentence, deleted ", without limitation," following "include" in accordance with 2013, No. 5, § 4.

Amendments--2009 (Adj. Sess.) Subsec. (c): Inserted "civil division of the" preceding "superior court".

Amendments--1985 (Adj. Sess.) Subsec. (a): Act No. 148 inserted "other than for the general assembly" following "for any office".

Subsec. (g): Repealed by Act No. 196.

Amendments--1981 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (g): Added.

Amendments--1979 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (c): Substituted "the election in question, or if there is a recount, within 10 days after the court issues its judgment on the recount" for "a primary or any other election" following "15 days after" in the first sentence.

Subsec. (f): Added.

ANNOTATIONS

Analysis

  • 1.Prior law.
  • 2.Constitutionality.
1. Prior law.

For decisions under prior provisions relating to the subject matter of this section, see annotations under former § 512 of this title.

2. Constitutionality.

This section and section 2617 of this title, purporting to confer general jurisdiction on the Superior Court to hear and determine matters relating to elections, insofar as they relate to elections to the House of Representatives, are an improper delegation of legislative powers to a separate branch of government, the Judicial Branch, contrary to the separation of powers doctrine set forth in Chapter II, section 5 of the Vermont Constitution. Kennedy v. Chittenden, 142 Vt. 397, 457 A.2d 626 (1983).

Since whatever result reached in a judicial adjudication contemplated under this section is subject to total revision or reversal by the exercise by the General Assembly of its acknowledged power over its own members as provided in Chapter II, section 14 of the Vermont Constitution, such power of revision, whether exercised or not, represents an intrusion prohibited by the doctrine of separation of powers and runs contrary to the precept that the exercise of judicial authority must lead to a final enforceable result and not be merely informative or advisory. Kennedy v. Chittenden, 142 Vt. 397, 457 A.2d 626 (1983).

An election contest initiated in Superior Court had no support in law, and the Superior Court was without jurisdiction to hear and determine the cause as stated in the complaint, inasmuch as this section and section 2617 of this title, purporting to confer general jurisdiction in election matters on the Superior Court, insofar as they related to elections to the House of Representatives, were violative of the constitutional doctrine of separation of powers since they improperly delegated legislative powers to the Judicial Branch in providing for a judicial determination as to the qualifications of electors and since the judicial adjudication contemplated under these sections was subject to revision or reversal by the General Assembly. Kennedy v. Chittenden, 142 Vt. 397, 457 A.2d 626 (1983).

Cited. Cota v. Town School District of Starksboro, 144 Vt. 633, 481 A.2d 1267 (1984); Putter v. Montpelier Public School System, 166 Vt. 463, 697 A.2d 354 (1997).

§ 2604. Repealed. 1985, No. 148 (Adj. Sess.), § 7.

History

Former § 2604. Former § 2604, relating to nonabridgment of the State Constitution, was derived from 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1.

§ 2605. House of Representatives.

  1. A candidate for the office of Representative to the General Assembly in the general election, or any elected town officer in the representative district, or any 25 voters in the representative district may request the House of Representatives to exercise its constitutional authority to judge the elections and qualifications of its own members, by filing a written request with the Secretary of State specifying the candidate or candidates whose election is being challenged. The request must be filed not later than the latest of the following:
    1. 20 days after the date of the election; or
    2. 10 days after a final court judgment, if there is a recount under section 2602 of this title.
    1. The Secretary of State shall notify the Attorney General, who shall investigate the facts, take such depositions as may be necessary, prepare an opinion on the law and facts, and send his or her report and opinion to the Clerk of the House at least 10 days before the General Assembly convenes. (b) (1) The Secretary of State shall notify the Attorney General, who shall investigate the facts, take such depositions as may be necessary, prepare an opinion on the law and facts, and send his or her report and opinion to the Clerk of the House at least 10 days before the General Assembly convenes.
    2. If the Attorney General needs additional time to conduct the investigation or prepare the report and opinion required by this subsection, he or she shall alert the Clerk of the House of that need and the date by which he or she plans to submit the report and opinion.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1979, No. 200 (Adj. Sess.), § 96; 2017, No. 50, § 47.

History

Amendments--2017. Subsec. (a): Deleted "of" following "authority to judge" in the first sentence and substituted "not" for "no" in the last sentence.

Subdiv. (a)(1): Added "or" at the end.

Subdiv. (a)(2): Deleted "; or" from the end.

Subdiv. (a)(3): Deleted.

Subsec. (b): Amended generally.

Amendments--1979 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (a): Deleted "not later than 10 days after the date of the election" following "with the secretary of state" in the first sentence and added the second sentence.

§ 2606. Senate.

  1. A candidate for the office of State Senator in the general election or any 100 voters in the senatorial district may request the Senate to exercise its constitutional authority to judge the elections and qualifications of its own members by filing a written request with the Secretary of State specifying the candidate or candidates whose election is being challenged. The request must be filed not later than the latest of the following:
    1. 20 days after the date of the election; or
    2. 10 days after a final court judgment, if there is a recount under section 2602 of this title.
    1. The Secretary of State shall notify the Attorney General, who shall investigate the facts, take such depositions as may be necessary, prepare an opinion on the law and facts, and send his or her report and opinion to the Secretary of the Senate at least 10 days before the General Assembly convenes. (b) (1) The Secretary of State shall notify the Attorney General, who shall investigate the facts, take such depositions as may be necessary, prepare an opinion on the law and facts, and send his or her report and opinion to the Secretary of the Senate at least 10 days before the General Assembly convenes.
    2. If the Attorney General needs additional time to conduct the investigation or prepare the report and opinion required by this subsection, he or she shall alert the Secretary of the Senate of that need and the date by which he or she plans to submit the report and opinion.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1979, No. 200 (Adj. Sess.), § 97; 2017, No. 50, § 48.

History

Amendments--2017. Subsec. (a): Deleted "of" following "authority to judge" in the first sentence and substituted "not" for "no" in the last sentence.

Subdiv. (a)(1): Added "or" at the end.

Subdiv. (a)(2): Deleted "; or" from the end.

Subdiv. (a)(3): Deleted.

Subsec. (b): Amended generally.

Amendments--1979 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (a): Deleted "not later than 10 days after the date of the election" following "with the secretary of state" in the first sentence and added the second sentence.

§ 2607. Canvassing committee.

The canvassing committee for State and national offices shall meet at 10:00 a.m. one week after the day of election to certify the results of the presidential primary. The chair of each major political party shall be given a copy of the official certificate of votes for the election.

Added 1995, No. 38, § 1.

Subchapter 10. Jurisdiction of Courts

§ 2616. Jurisdiction to prosecute criminal offenses.

The State's Attorney in any county in which all or a part of any violation of this title was committed shall have authority to prosecute such violations. The prosecution shall be conducted before the Vermont Criminal Division of the Superior Court.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 2009, No. 154 (Adj. Sess.), § 238.

History

Amendments--2009 (Adj. Sess.) Substituted "criminal division of the superior court" for "district court" in the second sentence.

§ 2617. Jurisdiction of Superior Courts.

In all cases for which no other provision has been made, the Superior Court shall have general jurisdiction to hear and determine matters relating to elections and to fashion appropriate relief.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1.

ANNOTATIONS

1. Constitutionality.

Section 2603 of this title, governing contest of elections, and this section, purporting to confer general jurisdiction on the Superior Court to hear and determine matters relating to elections, insofar as they relate to elections to the House of Representatives, are an improper delegation of legislative powers to a separate branch of government, the Judicial Branch, contrary to the separation of powers doctrine set forth in Chapter II, section 5 of the Vermont Constitution. Kennedy v. Chittenden, 142 Vt. 397, 457 A.2d 626 (1983).

An election contest initiated in Superior Court had no support in law, and the Superior Court was without jurisdiction to hear and determine the cause as stated in the complaint, inasmuch as section 2603 of this title providing procedures for contests of elections and this section, purporting to confer general jurisdiction in election matters on the Superior Court, insofar as they related to elections to the House of Representatives, were violative of the constitutional doctrine of separation of powers since they improperly delegated legislative powers to the Judicial Branch in providing for a judicial determination as to the qualifications of electors and since the judicial adjudication contemplated under these sections was subject to revision or reversal by the General Assembly. Kennedy v. Chittenden, 142 Vt. 397, 457 A.2d 626 (1983).

CHAPTER 53. VACANCIES

Sec.

  • 2621. Vacancy in office of U.S. Senator or Representative.
  • 2622. Interim appointment of U.S. Senator.
  • 2623. Vacancies in offices within this State.

§ 2621. Vacancy in office of U.S. Senator or Representative.

If a vacancy occurs in the office of U.S. Senator or U.S. Representative, the Governor shall call a special election to fill the vacancy. His or her proclamation shall specify a day for the special election and a day for a special primary, pursuant to section 2352 of this title.

(b) The special election shall be held not more than six months from the date the vacancy occurs, except that if the vacancy occurs within six months of a general election, the special election may be held the same day as the general election provided the ballots for the special election are able to be distributed by the deadline set forth in section 2479 of this title.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 2019, No. 67, § 18.

History

Amendments--2019. Added subsec. designations (a) and (b), and inserted "provided the ballots for the special election are able to be distributed by the deadline set forth in section 2479 of this title" following "same day as the general election" in subsec. (b).

ANNOTATIONS

1. Prior law.

For decisions under prior provisions relating to the subject matter of this section, see annotations under former §§ 1501 and 1701 of this title.

Cited. , Op. Atty. Gen. 94-2F.

§ 2622. Interim appointment of U.S. Senator.

The Governor may make an interim appointment to fill a vacancy in the office of U.S. Senator, pending the filling of the vacancy by special election.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1.

ANNOTATIONS

1. Prior law.

For decisions under prior provisions relating to the subject matter of this section, see annotations under former § 1502 of this title.

Cited. , Op. Atty. Gen. 94-2F.

§ 2623. Vacancies in offices within this State.

  1. In the event of a vacancy in any State, county, or legislative office, the Governor may request the political party or parties of the person whose death or resignation created the vacancy to submit one or more recommendations as to a successor. The proper committee to which a request for recommendation shall be directed shall be:
    1. for State officers, the State committee;
    2. for county officers, except justices of the peace and Probate judges, the county committee;
    3. for State Senator, the senatorial district committee;
    4. for State Representative, the representative district committee;
    5. for justice of the peace, the town committee;
    6. for Probate judge, the probate district committee.
  2. The Governor may appoint a qualified person to fill the vacancy for the remaining portion of the term, whether or not the appointee is recommended by the party committee.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1981, No. 239 (Adj. Sess.), § 20; 2013, No. 161 (Adj. Sess.), § 44.

History

2002. Undesignated paragraphs were designated as subsecs. (a) and (b) to conform section to V.S.A. style.

Amendments--2013 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (a): Inserted "or parties" following "the political party".

Amendments--1981 (Adj. Sess.). Subdiv. (2): Inserted "except justices of the peace and probate judges" following "county officers".

Subdiv. (5): Added.

Subdiv. (6): Added.

ANNOTATIONS

Cited. , Op. Atty. Gen. 94-2F.

Cross References

Cross references. Conduct of elections generally, see chapter 51 of this title.

Filling of vacancies in county offices, see § 2623 of this title.

Presidential elections, see chapter 57 of this title.

Subchapter 1. Scope

§ 2630. Applicability.

Except as otherwise provided, and to the extent that such a construction would be reasonable, the provisions of this title shall apply to this chapter.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1.

§ 2631. Municipal charters.

  1. Unless otherwise provided by law, when the charter of a municipality provides for procedures other than those established by law, the provisions of that charter shall prevail.
  2. Except as provided in subsection (a) of this section, all provisions of law relating to a municipality shall apply to such a municipality with a charter.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 2005, No. M-13 (Adj. Sess.), § 21; 2017, No. 99 (Adj. Sess.), § 1, eff. April 11, 2018.

History

Amendments--2017 (Adj. Sess.). Substituted "charters" for "charter" in the section heading and added the subsec. (a) designation and subsec. (b).

Amendments--2005 (Adj. Sess.). Substituted "Unless otherwise provided by law, when" for "Where" and "law" for "this chapter".

ANNOTATIONS

Cited. Town of Brattleboro v. Garfield, 180 Vt. 90, 904 A.2d 1157 (June 16, 2006).

Subchapter 2. Town Meetings and Local Elections in General

§ 2640. Annual meetings.

  1. A meeting of the legal voters of each town shall be held annually on the first Tuesday of March for the election of officers and the transaction of other business, and it may be adjourned to another date. When a municipality fails to hold an annual meeting, a warning for a subsequent meeting shall be issued immediately, and at that meeting all the officers required by law may be elected and its business transacted.
  2. When a town so votes, it may thereafter start its annual meeting on any of the three days immediately preceding the first Tuesday in March at such time as it elects and may transact at that time any business not involving voting by Australian ballot or voting required by law to be by ballot and to be held on the first Tuesday in March. A meeting so started shall be adjourned until the first Tuesday in March.
    1. Notwithstanding section 2508 of this title, public discussion of ballot issues and all other issues appearing in the warning, other than election of candidates, shall be permitted at the annual meeting, regardless of the location of the polling place. (c) (1) Notwithstanding section 2508 of this title, public discussion of ballot issues and all other issues appearing in the warning, other than election of candidates, shall be permitted at the annual meeting, regardless of the location of the polling place.
    2. Notwithstanding the provisions of subdivision (1) of this subsection, a candidate for local office nominated from the floor at the annual meeting may introduce his or her candidacy to the extent permitted by the voters at the meeting.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1991, No. 118 (Adj. Sess.), § 1, eff. Feb. 26, 1992; 2007, No. 121 (Adj. Sess.), § 11; 2013, No. 161 (Adj. Sess.), § 45; 2017, No. 50, § 49.

History

Amendments--2017. Subsec. (c): Added the subdiv. (1) designation and deleted "on that day" following "permitted" in that subdiv. and added subdiv. (2).

Amendments--2013 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (a): Substituted "When a municipality" for "When a town" at the beginning of the second sentence.

Amendments--2007 (Adj. Sess.) Subsec. (c): Substituted "Notwithstanding section 2508 of this title" for "In a town which starts its annual meeting on any day before the first Tuesday in March and which uses the Australian ballot system".

Amendments--1991 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (b): Substituted "on any of the three days immediately preceding the first Tuesday in March at such time as it elects" for "at 7:30 o'clock in the afternoon of the day before the first Tuesday of March" following "meeting" in the first sentence, "in" for "of" preceding "March" at the end of that sentence, and "first Tuesday in March" for "following day" following "until the" in the second sentence.

Subsec. (c): Substituted "any" for "the" following "meeting on" and deleted "preceding" following "permitted on that" at the end of the subsec.

ANNOTATIONS

Analysis

  • 1.Construction.
  • 2.Failure to hold meeting.
  • 3.Powers of town meeting.
  • 4.Mandamus.
  • 5.Opportunity for discussion.
1. Construction.

Provision that meeting of voters shall be annually held in each town for election of officers and transaction of other business, at which meeting certain enumerated officers shall be chosen, are positive legislative commands and voters may not decide when or how often they shall hold an election. Jenney v. Alden, 79 Vt. 156, 64 A. 609 (1906). (Decided under prior law.)

2. Failure to hold meeting.

Adjournment of town meeting without electing officers or transacting the business warned amounts to "a failure to hold such meeting," within the intent of this section. Jenney v. Alden, 79 Vt. 156, 64 A. 609 (1906). (Decided under prior law.)

3. Powers of town meeting.

Town meeting does not have power to instruct listers as to their duties or to instruct them to disregard property assessments made or approved by them. Royalton Taxpayers Protective Association v. Wassmansdorf, 128 Vt. 153, 260 A.2d 203 (1969). (Decided under prior law.)

Alteration or amendment of town grand tax list properly signed and filed by the listers, and substitution of a body other than the listers to set up a basis for property valuation for tax purposes, was beyond power of town meeting and no clear right was violated when selectboard refused to warn special town meeting sought by taxpayers, so that taxpayers were not entitled to mandamus to compel selectboard to warn meeting. Royalton Taxpayers Protective Association v. Wassmansdorf, 128 Vt. 153, 260 A.2d 203 (1969). (Decided under prior law.)

4. Mandamus.

Where voters without electing any of officers or transacting any of business specified in warning, adjourned the meeting, writ of mandamus will issue, on petition of resident voter and taxpayer, directing selectboard forthwith to call special town meeting for election of officers. Jenney v. Alden, 79 Vt. 156, 64 A. 609 (1906). (Decided under prior law.)

5. Opportunity for discussion.

Where Australian ballot system, calling for voting without discussion, was used at school district meeting, and voters were warned that they were to express approval or disapproval by marking ballot, failure to provide opportunity for discussion did not affect validity of the votes. Groton v. Union School Dist. 21, 127 Vt. 142, 241 A.2d 332 (1968). (Decided under prior law.)

Plaintiff may not claim that opportunity for discussion on bond issue voted on at school district meeting was denied, where no voter sought opportunity for discussion. Groton v. Union School Dist. 21, 127 Vt. 142, 241 A.2d 332 (1968). (Decided under prior law.)

§ 2640a. Representative annual meetings.

  1. A municipality with a population of 5,000 or greater may vote at a special or annual town meeting to establish a representative form of annual or special meeting.
    1. A representative form of annual or special meeting is a meeting of members elected by district to exercise the powers vested in the voters of the town to act upon articles. However, the election of officers, public questions, and all articles to be voted upon by Australian ballot as required by law or as voted under section 2680 of this title at a prior annual or special meeting, and reconsideration of articles under section 2661 of this title shall remain vested in the voters of the town. (b) (1) A representative form of annual or special meeting is a meeting of members elected by district to exercise the powers vested in the voters of the town to act upon articles. However, the election of officers, public questions, and all articles to be voted upon by Australian ballot as required by law or as voted under section 2680 of this title at a prior annual or special meeting, and reconsideration of articles under section 2661 of this title shall remain vested in the voters of the town.
    2. An organizational resolution to adopt a representative form of annual or special meeting may be made by the legislative body of the municipality or by petition of five percent of the voters of the municipality. An official copy of the organizational resolution shall be filed in the office of the clerk of the municipality at least 10 days before the annual or special meeting at which the vote whether to adopt the organizational resolution shall take place, and copies thereof shall be made available to members of the public upon request.
    3. An organizational resolution shall include the following:
      1. a certain number of elected members, a range of elected members, or a ratio of elected members to the number of voters. However, in no case shall the number of elected members be less than 100;
      2. a certain number of districts and the boundaries of those districts;
      3. who shall be ex officio voting members, if any, of the meeting;
      4. the procedure for conducting the representative meeting;
      5. specific action, if any, to be taken at the representative meeting; and
      6. a procedure whereby the voters of the municipality may reconsider any action taken at a representative meeting.
  3. The form of the question of whether to establish a representative form of annual or special meeting shall be substantially as follows: "Shall the [name of municipality] adopt the representative form of annual or special meeting as set forth in the organizational resolution?"
  4. A vote establishing a representative form of annual or special meeting shall remain in effect until the municipality votes to discontinue or establish a new representative form of annual or special meeting at an annual or special meeting duly warned for that purpose.

Added 2009, No. 125 (Adj. Sess.), § 1.

§ 2641. Warning and notice required; publication of warnings.

  1. The legislative body of a municipality shall warn a meeting by posting a warning and notice in at least two public places in the municipality, and in or near the town clerk's office, not less than 30 nor more than 40 days before the meeting. If a municipality has more than one polling place and the polling places are not all in the same building, the warning and notice shall be posted in at least two public places within each voting district and in or near the town clerk's office.
  2. In addition, the warning shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the municipality at least five days before the meeting, unless the warning is published in the town report and distributed as provided in 24 V.S.A. § 1682. The legislative body annually shall designate the paper in which such a warning may be published. The warning shall also be posted on the municipality's website, if the municipality actively updates its website on a regular basis.
  3. No such warning shall be required for municipal informational meetings at which no voting is to take place.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1979, No. 200 (Adj. Sess.), § 98; 1985, No. 196 (Adj. Sess.), § 5; 1999, No. 148 (Adj. Sess.), § 85, eff. May 24, 2000; 2013, No. 161 (Adj. Sess.), § 66.

History

Amendments--2013 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (a): Substituted "municipality" for "town" twice.

Subsec. (b): Substituted "and distributed as provided in 24 V.S.A. § 1682" for ", or otherwise distributed in written form to all town or city postal patrons at least 10 days before the meeting" at the end of the first sentence, and added the third sentence.

Subsec. (c): Added the designation.

Amendments--1999 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (b): Deleted "and the town report is mailed" following "town report", substituted "distributed in written form to all town or city postal patrons" for "distributed to the voters' in the first sentence, "which such a warning may by" for "which these warnings shall be" in the second sentence, and "No such warning shall be required for" for "This shall not apply to" in the third sentence.

Amendments--1985 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (b): Inserted "at least five days" following "municipality" in the first sentence.

Amendments--1979 (Adj. Sess.). Section amended generally.

ANNOTATIONS

Analysis

  • 1.Prior law.
  • 2.Generally.
  • 3.Power to warn meeting.
  • 4.Duty to warn meeting.
  • 5.Posting of notices.
1. Prior law.

For decisions under prior provisions relating to the subject matter of this section, see annotations under former §§ 861 and 1142 of this title.

2. Generally.

Issuance of warning for town school district meeting is not exercise of authority and control over school matters by selectboard for the school district, but issuance of such warning acts merely to set machinery in motion for holding of meeting. Baird v. Town of Berlin, 126 Vt. 348, 231 A.2d 110 (1967). (Decided under prior law.)

School directors need not sign warning for annual town meeting. 1944-46 Op. Atty. Gen. 99. (Decided under prior law.)

3. Power to warn meeting.

Town school directors have no power to legally warn town school district meeting; such power rests solely with selectboard for school district. Baird v. Town of Berlin, 126 Vt. 348, 231 A.2d 110 (1967). (Decided under prior law.)

4. Duty to warn meeting.

Where article proposed for inclusion in warning was to see if voters of school district would direct that the annual meeting be held not later than January 20 beginning in 1970, and course of litigation was such that supreme court's decision would come at a time when a vote on the question could very likely be taken only after January 20 or so near that date that the annual meeting could not be properly warned and held, mandamus would not be granted to compel school board to warn requested meeting of school district. Whiteman v. Brown, 128 Vt. 384, 264 A.2d 793 (1970). (Decided under prior law.)

Where petition of certain voters was filed with clerk of town school district requesting that special meeting be warned for purpose of reconsidering previous vote authorizing purchase of certain land on which new school building was to be erected, selectboard for school district had no option as to whether or not they would warn the meeting requested, but were compelled by statute to give such warning. Baird v. Town of Berlin, 126 Vt. 348, 231 A.2d 110 (1967). (Decided under prior law.)

Fact that petition by voters for meeting for reconsideration of previous vote authorizing purchase of land for site of new school building was filed with clerk of school district was of no consequence, since such was technical, if not substantial, compliance with statute, the matter presented being one within purview of selectboard for school district. Baird v. Town of Berlin, 126 Vt. 348, 231 A.2d 110 (1967). (Decided under prior law.)

5. Posting of notices.

It is no objection to legality of town meeting that notices for meeting were not posted by selectboard in places where such notices had usually been posted in town, it not appearing but that they were posted in public places. Stoddard v. Gilman, 22 Vt. 568 (1850). (Decided under prior law.)

§ 2642. Warning and notice contents.

    1. The warning shall include the date and time of the election, location of the polling place or places, and the nature of the meeting or election. (a) (1) The warning shall include the date and time of the election, location of the polling place or places, and the nature of the meeting or election.
    2. It shall, by separate articles, specifically indicate the business to be transacted, to include the offices and the questions to be voted upon.
      1. The warning shall also contain any article or articles requested by a petition signed by at least five percent of the voters of the municipality and filed with the municipal clerk not less than 47 days before the day of the meeting. (3) (A) The warning shall also contain any article or articles requested by a petition signed by at least five percent of the voters of the municipality and filed with the municipal clerk not less than 47 days before the day of the meeting.
      2. The clerk receiving the petitions shall immediately proceed to examine them to ascertain whether they contain the required number of signatures of registered voters set forth in subdivision (A) of this subdivision (3). If found not to conform, he or she shall state in writing on the petition why it cannot be accepted, and within 24 hours from receipt, he or she shall return it to the petitioners. In this case, supplementary petitions may be filed not later than 48 hours after the petition was returned to the petitioners by the clerk or the filing deadline set forth in subdivision (A) of this subdivision (3), whichever is later. However, supplementary petitions shall not be accepted if petitions with signatures of different persons totaling at least the number specified in subdivision (A) of this subdivision (3) were not filed by the filing deadline.
      3. A petition submitted under this subdivision (3):
        1. may include more than one proposed article;
        2. shall contain the petition language on each page on which signatures are collected; and
        3. shall include the printed name, signature, and street address of each voter who signed the petition.
      4. A voter may withdraw his or her name from a petitioned article at any time prior to the signing of the warning by a majority of the legislative body.
  2. The posted notice that accompanies the warning shall include information on voter registration, information on early or absentee voting where applicable, and other appropriate information.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1979, No. 200 (Adj. Sess.), § 99; 2001, No. 6, § 12(c), eff. April 10, 2001; 2013, No. 161 (Adj. Sess.), § 46; 2015, No. 30, § 23, eff. May 26, 2015.

History

Amendments--2015. Subdiv. (a)(3)(A): Substituted "47 days" for "45 days".

Subdiv. (a)(3)(B): Amended generally.

Subdivs. (a)(3)(C) and (D): Added.

Amendments--2013 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (a): Added the subdivision designations and substituted "45 days" for "40 days" following "not less than" in subdiv. (a)(3)(A).

Subdiv. (a)(3)(B): Added.

Amendments--2001. Subsec. (b): Inserted "early or" preceding "absentee voting".

Amendments--1979 (Adj. Sess.). Section amended generally.

ANNOTATIONS

Analysis

  • 1.School district budget.
  • 2.Construction.
  • 3.Construction with other laws.
  • 4.Scope of meeting.
  • 5.Sufficiency of statement generally.
  • 6.Authorization for vote.
  • 7.Mandamus in connection with warning.
  • 8.Injunction of proposed meeting.
  • 9.Question not previously submitted to voters.
  • 10. Reconsideration of previous vote.
  • 11. Authority of voters to decide.
1. School district budget.

School district budget could be established by Australian ballot only as proposed by its school board upon affirmative vote at the annual or subsequent meeting; therefore, petition signed by approximately ten percent of district's voters requesting that an article be included in the warning proposing a lower budget than that proposed by the board was for an unlawful purpose and correctly excluded from the warning. Pominville v. Addison Central Supervisory Union, 154 Vt. 299, 575 A.2d 196 (1990).

2. Construction.

If an article sought to be included in a warning does not in any way constitute business proper and appropriate for transaction at the meeting, this statute should not be construed to compel its inclusion. Whiteman v. Brown, 128 Vt. 384, 264 A.2d 793 (1970). (Decided under prior law.)

3. Construction with other laws.

Subsec. (a) of this section provides municipalities with discretion over whether to present an article to voters - even a nonbinding article included under 17 V.S.A. § 2103(27) - when it does not at all relate to municipal business or any matter falling within municipal authority. Clift v. City of South Burlington, 181 Vt. 571, 917 A.2d 483 (mem.) (January 18, 2007).

Where two statutes may apply to a single circumstance, with conflicting consequences, the general statute must yield to the special; hence, an attempt by a town under the provisions of this section to reconsider its favorable vote on joining a union high school district was, under the provisions of 16 V.S.A. § 662(a) and (d), null and void where the vote to withdraw from the district was taken less than a year after the district had become a body politic and corporate. Appelget & Elliott v. Baird, 126 Vt. 503, 236 A.2d 671 (1967). (Decided under prior law.)

Charter of City of Burlington delegates to City right to fix, by standing bylaw, time and extent of publication, and is not controlled by this section, which provides how town meetings shall be warned. Allan v. Burlington, 45 Vt. 202 (1873). (Decided under prior law.)

4. Scope of meeting.

Towns at annual March meeting, or at adjourned term of same in April, may transact any business within scope of their corporate interests, whether subject matter of business is named in warrant for meeting or not. Schoff v. Bloomfield, 8 Vt. 472 (1836). (Decided under prior law.)

5. Sufficiency of statement generally.

The warning of a municipal meeting shall set forth the business to be done and the subjects to be considered with such reasonable certainty as will notify all interested in the subject matter of the proposed vote or action and the time and place of the meeting. Brochu v. Brown, 128 Vt. 549, 268 A.2d 745 (1970). (Decided under prior law.)

To comply with requirement that warning of town meeting shall set forth "the business to be done and subjects to be considered," all that is necessary is that they shall be stated with such reasonable certainty as will indicate to all interested subject matter of proposed action by town. Walsh v. Farrington, 105 Vt. 269, 165 A. 914 (1933). (Decided under prior law.)

All that is necessary in warning for town meeting to raise money is that it should set forth, in general terms, purposes or objects for which money is to be raised, with such reasonable certainty as will notify all interested of subject matter of proposed vote or action of town, and time and place of meeting. Alger v. Curry, 40 Vt. 437 (1868), same case 38 Vt. 382. (Decided under prior law.)

6. Authorization for vote.

Under a warning to see if district will "vote to raise money to pay the district expenses," a vote to "raise money to support the school and pay the indebtedness of the district" was sufficiently definite. Adams v. Sleeper, 64 Vt. 544, 24 A. 990 (1892). (Decided under prior law.)

Warning to see if town will vote tax for purpose of paying bounty did not authorize vote to borrow money for this purpose. Atwood v. Lincoln, 44 Vt. 332 (1872). (Decided under prior law.)

Where warning was "to consider the propriety of paying bounties to such persons as may enlist" to fill an existing quota, and vote was "to pay to each volunteer to fill the required quota," vote had reference to those who should thereafter enlist. Sargent v. Ludlow, 42 Vt. 726 (1870). (Decided under prior law.)

Where warning contained following articles: "To see whether the town will vote bounties to supply the quota of the said town under the recent call of the President of the United States for 300,000 men to serve in the war. In case the town shall vote to pay such bounties, to raise and provide means for the same," and vote was: "that the selectmen be instructed to borrow a sum not exceeding $3000, for the purpose of paying $300 each to volunteers that may hereafter enlist for the war, under the recent call of the President of the United States, including the one that is understood has enlisted, payment to be made such enlisted men when mustered in to the service of the United States," there was no such difference between warning and vote as to render latter inoperative. Mudget v. Johnson, 42 Vt. 423 (1869). (Decided under prior law.)

Warning of town meeting to see if town would vote to divide school district and to make such other alterations in school districts in town as might be found necessary, was sufficiently definite to warrant vote of town to form a new district out of portion of territory of school district which was specified in vote. Weeks v. Batchelder, 41 Vt. 317 (1868). (Decided under prior law.)

Words "to ascertain whether the town would vote a tax on the grand list for the purpose of paying bounties to soldiers, and paying its indebtedness," in warning for town meeting, were sufficient on general demurrer to justify town in raising money to pay bounties to soldiers, and indebtedness of the town. Alger v. Curry, 40 Vt. 437 (1868), same case 38 Vt. 382. (Decided under prior law.)

Vote of town meeting instructing selectboard to procure recruits for town and empowering selectboard to borrow funds on five years credit for town to pay bounties to such recruits, was not warranted by a warning to see if town would raise a tax upon grand list to pay recruits, and how much and when, and to instruct selectboard in disposal of funds so raised. Blush v. Colchester, 39 Vt. 193 (1867). (Decided under prior law.)

Where warning was, "to see if the town will raise money to pay the bounty promised to soldiers," and under that article town "voted to raise fifty-five cents on the dollar of the grand list, to pay the bounty offered to soldiers," vote was sufficiently particular and definite and object specified was within powers of the town. Blodgett v. Holbrook, 39 Vt. 336 (1866). (Decided under prior law.)

Article in warning of town meeting as follows: "To see if the town will make alterations in school districts when met," was sufficient to warrant consideration by town in town meeting of any proposed changes in limits of existing school districts. Ovitt v. Chase, 37 Vt. 196 (1864). (Decided under prior law.)

Where article in warning for town meeting was to see if town would divide school district, and annex portion of it to one district and remainder to another, town could at such meeting legally set whole of district proposed to be divided to either of the other districts named in warning. Moore v. Beattie, 33 Vt. 219 (1860). (Decided under prior law.)

7. Mandamus in connection with warning.

Article to see if the voters of school district would direct school board to have an audit of all financial and related records of the district for the three preceding school years made by an accounting firm was inappropriate for inclusion in warning for special meeting as it did not deal with proper and appropriate business, therefore, Supreme Court could not issue mandamus to require school board to include the article in the warning. Whiteman v. Brown, 128 Vt. 384, 264 A.2d 793 (1970). (Decided under prior law.)

Mandamus would not be issued to compel school board to warn requested special meeting of school district where one of the two proposed articles to be warned concerned business which it was not proper for the meeting to transact and the other concerned a moot issue, thus leaving petition for meeting without any proposal of business to be transacted. Whiteman v. Brown, 128 Vt. 384, 264 A.2d 793 (1970). (Decided under prior law.)

8. Injunction of proposed meeting.

Petition alleging that previous vote authorizing school board to purchase land as site for new school building could not be reconsidered and that any subsequent town meeting, held for purpose of reconsidering such vote, would be without legal effect stated no basis for issuance of injunction enjoining the proposed meeting. Baird v. Town of Berlin, 126 Vt. 348, 231 A.2d 110 (1967). (Decided under prior law.)

9. Question not previously submitted to voters.

In action by legal voters of town school district to restrain reconsideration of vote authorizing school board to purchase land for purpose of constructing new school building thereon, finding that the vote "had never been previously submitted to the legal voters" was not inconsistent with finding that petition was filed which requested that another special school district meeting be held for purpose of reconsidering the vote. Baird v. Town of Berlin, 126 Vt. 348, 231 A.2d 110 (1967). (Decided under prior law.)

Questions voted at previous town school district meetings relating to the purchase on "site no. 2," purchase of land "under option," authorization of bond issue to buy Pike site and construct new school building thereon, and the purchase of Pike site for larger sum than that voted at June 6, 1966, meeting were substantively different than question voted on at June 6 meeting authorizing school board to purchase Pike land for purpose of constructing new school building thereon, thus permitting reconsideration of the June 6 vote under this section. Baird v. Town of Berlin, 126 Vt. 348, 231 A.2d 110 (1967). (Decided under prior law.)

10. Reconsideration of previous vote.

Where petition of certain voters was filed with clerk of town school district requesting that special meeting be warned for purpose of reconsidering previous vote authorizing purchase of certain land on which new school building was to be erected, selectboard for school district had no option as to whether or not they would warn the meeting requested, but were compelled by 16 V.S.A. § 362 to give such warning. Baird v. Town of Berlin, 126 Vt. 348, 231 A.2d 110 (1967). (Decided under prior law.)

Fact that petition by voters for meeting for reconsideration of previous vote authorizing purchase of land for site of new school building was filed with clerk of school district was of no consequence, since such was technical, if not substantial, compliance with this section, the matter presented being one within purview of selectboard for school district. Baird v. Town of Berlin, 126 Vt. 348, 231 A.2d 110 (1967). (Decided under prior law.)

Voters of town school district who desired reconsideration of previous vote on question of purchase of land for purpose of constructing new school building thereon complied with statute requiring that such petition be filed with legislative branch of municipality, where they filed their petition for meeting with clerk of town school district. Baird v. Town of Berlin, 126 Vt. 348, 231 A.2d 110 (1967). (Decided under prior law.)

A town which voted in the negative on the question of permitting the local sale of malt and vinous beverages and spirituous liquors at its annual meeting as required at the meeting by 7 V.S.A. § 161 may legally reconsider the question at a subsequent special meeting under the provisions of this section. 1966-68 Op. Atty. Gen. 129. (Decided under prior law.)

11. Authority of voters to decide.

Statutory duty of the school board to warn items concerning the "business to be transacted" means that petitioned items of business must be within the authority of voters to decide at town meeting. In the context of a school district, the petitioned items of business must be within the authority of voters to decide at a district meeting. Skiff v. S. Burlington Sch. Dist., 208 Vt. 564, 201 A.3d 969 (2018).

Because the duty of the school board to warn of items concerning the "business to be transacted" meant that petitioned items of business had to be within the authority of voters to decide, and the name of the school district's sports teams was not a matter within voters' authority to decide at a district-wide meeting, the district was not required by statute to put the issue to a district-wide vote, although it could have elected to do so if it wished. Skiff v. S. Burlington Sch. Dist., 208 Vt. 564, 201 A.3d 969 (2018).

Cited. Addison County Community Action Group v. City of Vergennes, 152 Vt. 161, 565 A.2d 233 (1989).

§ 2643. Special meetings.

  1. The legislative body may warn a special municipal meeting when it deems it necessary and shall call a special meeting on the application of five percent of the voters. A special meeting shall be warned within 60 days of receipt of the application by the municipal clerk. A voter may withdraw his or her name from a petition for a special meeting at any time prior to the signing of the warning by a majority of the legislative body.
  2. [Repealed.]
  3. The legislative body may rescind the call of a special meeting called by them but not a special meeting called on application of five percent of the voters.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 2013, No. 161 (Adj. Sess.), § 47; 2015, No. 30, § 24, eff. May 26, 2015.

History

Revision note. In subsec. (a), in the first sentence, substituted "it deems" for "they deem" to correct a grammatical error.

Amendments--2015. Subsec. (a): Substituted "60 days" for "15 days" and "municipal clerk" for "town clerk" in the second sentence and added the third sentence.

Amendments--2013 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (a): Substituted "warned" for "called" preceding "within 15 days" and "town clerk" for "legislative body" at the end.

Subsec. (b): Repealed.

ANNOTATIONS

Analysis

  • 1.Meeting demanded by voters.
  • 2.Construction.
  • 3.Mandamus.
  • 4.Injunction of proposed meeting.
  • 5.Resubmission of issues.
  • 6.Rescission of vote.
1. Meeting demanded by voters.

Because the charter of the Town of Brattleboro creates a separate and specific avenue for filling a single vacancy on the town selectboard without leaving room for the special meeting petition, this section does not apply. Town of Brattleboro v. Garfield, 180 Vt. 90, 904 A.2d 1157 (June 16, 2006).

Where more than five percent of town's registered voters signed a petition demanding a special town meeting on an agreement entered into by the selectboard, the selectboard did not have a duty to call the meeting, since if the selectboard had the power to make the agreement, it was legally binding and the voters could not undo it, and if the selectboard did not have the power to make the agreement, it was invalid irrespective of the call for a meeting. Kirchner v. Giebink, 150 Vt. 172, 552 A.2d 372 (1988).

Where voters at annual town meeting voted to increase size of selectboard from three to five without also electing the individuals to fill the two vacancies, and thereafter at least five percent of the legal voters of the town signed petition requesting special town meeting to elect two additional selectboard members failure of defendant selectboard members to promptly warn for, and hold, requested town meeting was violation of their statutory duty to do so. Welton v. Town of Brandon, 132 Vt. 74, 313 A.2d 676 (1973). (Decided under prior law.)

2. Construction.

The Legislature did not intend this section to be used to compel selectboard to hold a special town meeting for a useless, frivolous, or unlawful purpose. Royalton Taxpayers Protective Association v. Wassmansdorf, 128 Vt. 153, 260 A.2d 203 (1969). (Decided under prior law.)

Legislature's intention in enacting this section was to allow the selectboard to be compelled to call a special meeting upon a properly drawn petition showing a clear right which is within the province of the town meeting to grant or refuse through its vote. Royalton Taxpayers Protective Association v. Wassmansdorf, 128 Vt. 153, 260 A.2d 203 (1969). (Decided under prior law.)

3. Mandamus.

Where result of proposed special town meeting to vote on the appropriateness of the Rutland Housing Authority's selection of a single site for the development of low-income housing under federal project would only be advisory and not binding on the authority, mandamus would not issue to compel the mayor to call the meeting, as the effect of the issuance would be nugatory and serve no lawful purpose. Brewster v. Mayor of Rutland, 128 Vt. 437, 266 A.2d 428 (1970). (Decided under prior law.)

Alteration or amendment of town grand tax list properly signed and filed by the listers, and substitution of a body other than the listers to set up a basis for property valuation for tax purposes, was beyond power of town meeting and no clear right was violated when selectboard refused to warn special town meeting sought by taxpayers, so that taxpayers were not entitled to mandamus to compel selectboard to warn meeting. Royalton Taxpayers Protective Association v. Wassmansdorf, 128 Vt. 153, 260 A.2d 203 (1969). (Decided under prior law.)

4. Injunction of proposed meeting.

In suit to enjoin calling of special town meeting to see whether town would vote to rescind its previous action in voting to exempt manufacturing corporation from local taxation for period of five years, after corporation had accepted offer by rebuilding its plant and resuming its business, where there was no allegation that action adverse to corporation was threatened at such town meeting, and no facts were set forth whereby it could be determined whether such an outcome was certain or even probable, petition was prematurely brought, and petitioner was not entitled to injunctive relief. Rixford Mfg. Co. v. Highgate, 102 Vt. 1, 144 A. 680 (1929). (Decided under prior law.)

5. Resubmission of issues.

Petition presented to selectboard requesting a vote on whether action taken by past town meeting, filed more than thirty days after the vote taken at such town meeting, was out of time, and any vote on the matter requested to be voted upon would have been of no force and effect and nugatory. Royalton Taxpayers Protective Association v. Wassmansdorf, 128 Vt. 153, 260 A.2d 203 (1969). (Decided under prior law.)

6. Rescission of vote.

Where town voted to raise tax, but nothing was done under the vote, town had power, at meeting legally warned for that purpose, to rescind or reconsider the vote; and having done so, collector could not legally proceed to collect tax. Stoddard v. Gilman, 22 Vt. 568 (1850). (Decided under prior law.)

§ 2644. Warnings.

The original warning for each municipal meeting shall be signed by a majority of the legislative body and shall be filed with the clerk and recorded before being posted. When all positions on the legislative body are vacant, warnings may be signed by the clerk.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1.

ANNOTATIONS

1. Failure to record.

Proceedings of school district meeting were not void because clerk failed to record the warning in accordance with this section. Adams v. Sleeper, 64 Vt. 544, 24 A. 990 (1892). (Decided under prior law.)

§ 2645. Charters; adoption, repeal, or amendment; procedure.

  1. A municipality may propose to the General Assembly to adopt, repeal, or amend its charter by majority vote of the legal voters of the municipality present and voting at any annual or special meeting warned for that purpose in accordance with the following procedure:
    1. A proposal to adopt, repeal, or amend a municipal charter (charter proposal) may be made by the legislative body of the municipality or by petition of five percent of the voters of the municipality.
    2. An official copy of the charter proposal shall be filed as a public record in the office of the clerk of the municipality at least 10 days before the first public hearing. The clerk shall certify the date on which he or she received the official copy, and the dated copies thereof shall be made available to members of the public upon request.
      1. The legislative body of the municipality shall hold at least two public hearings prior to the meeting to vote on the charter proposal. (3) (A) The legislative body of the municipality shall hold at least two public hearings prior to the meeting to vote on the charter proposal.
      2. The first public hearing shall be held in accordance with subdivision (a)(2) of this section and at least 30 days before the vote.
      1. If the charter proposal is made by the legislative body, the legislative body may revise the proposal as a result of suggestions and recommendations made at a public hearing, but in no event shall such revisions be made less than 20 days before the date of the meeting to vote on the charter proposal. (4) (A) If the charter proposal is made by the legislative body, the legislative body may revise the proposal as a result of suggestions and recommendations made at a public hearing, but in no event shall such revisions be made less than 20 days before the date of the meeting to vote on the charter proposal.
      2. If revisions are made, the legislative body shall post a notice of these revisions in the same places as the warning for the meeting not less than 20 days before the date of the meeting and shall attach such revisions to the official copy kept on file for public inspection in the office of the clerk of the municipality.
      1. If the charter proposal is made by petition, the second public hearing shall be held no later than 10 days after the first public hearing. The legislative body shall not have the authority to revise a charter proposal made by petition. (5) (A) If the charter proposal is made by petition, the second public hearing shall be held no later than 10 days after the first public hearing. The legislative body shall not have the authority to revise a charter proposal made by petition.
      2. After the warning and hearing requirements of this section are satisfied, the petitioned charter proposal shall be submitted to the voters at the next annual meeting, primary, or general election in the form in which it was filed, except that the legislative body may make technical corrections.
      1. Notice of each public hearing and of the annual or special meeting shall be given in accordance with section 2641 of this chapter. (6) (A) Notice of each public hearing and of the annual or special meeting shall be given in accordance with section 2641 of this chapter.
        1. Each notice shall specify the charter sections to be adopted, repealed, or amended, setting out those sections in the amended form, with deleted matter struck through and new matter underlined. (B) (i) Each notice shall specify the charter sections to be adopted, repealed, or amended, setting out those sections in the amended form, with deleted matter struck through and new matter underlined.
        2. If the legislative body of the municipality determines that the charter proposal is too long or unwieldy to set out in amended form, the notice shall include a concise summary of the charter proposal and shall state that an official copy of the charter proposal is on file for public inspection in the office of the clerk of the municipality and that copies thereof shall be made available to members of the public upon request.
      1. Voting on a charter proposal shall be by Australian ballot. (7) (A) Voting on a charter proposal shall be by Australian ballot.
        1. The ballot shall show each charter section to be adopted, repealed, or amended in the amended form, with deleted matter struck through and new matter underlined, and shall permit the voter to vote on each separate proposal contained within the charter proposal. (B) (i) The ballot shall show each charter section to be adopted, repealed, or amended in the amended form, with deleted matter struck through and new matter underlined, and shall permit the voter to vote on each separate proposal contained within the charter proposal.
        2. If the legislative body determines that the charter proposal is too long or unwieldy to be shown in the amended form, voters shall be permitted to vote upon each separate proposal in its entirety in the form of a yes or no proposition.
      3. An official copy of the charter proposal shall be posted conspicuously in each ballot booth for inspection by the voters during the balloting.
    1. The clerk of the municipality, under the direction of the legislative body, shall announce and post the results of the vote immediately after the vote is counted. (b) (1) The clerk of the municipality, under the direction of the legislative body, shall announce and post the results of the vote immediately after the vote is counted.
    2. The clerk, within 10 days after the day of the meeting, shall certify to the Secretary of State each separate proposal contained within the charter proposal, showing the facts as to its origin and the procedure followed, which shall include:
        1. If the charter proposal was made by the legislative body, the minutes recorded by the legislative body that detail the origins and intent of each separate proposal; (A) (i) If the charter proposal was made by the legislative body, the minutes recorded by the legislative body that detail the origins and intent of each separate proposal;
        2. If the charter proposal was made by voter petition, the body of the petition and evidence of the required number of petition signatures;
      2. A copy of the official certified copy of the charter proposal filed with the clerk of the municipality pursuant to subdivision (a)(2) of this section;
      3. Copies of the warnings and published notices for each of the public hearings held pursuant to subdivision (a)(3) of this section;
      4. Minutes recorded by the legislative body that detail each of the public hearings held pursuant to subdivision (a)(3) of this section;
      5. Copies of warnings and published notices for the meeting to vote on the charter proposal; and
      6. A copy of the ballot and the results of the vote or votes on the charter proposal.
  3. After confirming that the clerk of the municipality has certified each of the documents listed in subdivision (b)(2) of this section, the Secretary of State shall file the certificate and deliver copies of it to the Attorney General, the Clerk of the House, the Secretary of the Senate, and the chairs of the committees concerned with municipal charters of both houses of the General Assembly.
  4. The charter proposal shall become effective upon affirmative enactment of the proposal, either as proposed or as amended by the General Assembly.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1979, No. 200 (Adj. Sess.), § 100; 1981, No. 239 (Adj. Sess.), § 22, eff. May 4, 1982; 1983, No. 161 (Adj. Sess.); 1987, No. 63; 2017, No. M-7, § 2A, eff. May 22, 2017.

History

Amendments--2017. Section amended generally.

Amendments--1987. Subsec. (a): Amended generally.

Amendments--1983 (Adj. Sess.). Section amended generally.

Amendments--1981 (Adj. Sess.). Subdiv. (a)(4): Added the last sentence.

Amendments--1979 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (b): Amended generally.

ANNOTATIONS

Analysis

  • 1.Constitutionality.
  • 2.Application.
  • 3.Amendment by Legislature.
  • 4.Construction.
1. Constitutionality.

This section is not an unconstitutional delegation of the legislative function. 1970-72 Op. Atty. Gen. 303. (Decided under prior law.)

2. Application.

This section authorizes towns to propose even those charter amendments which conflict with State statutes, so that a town may amend its charter to set speed limits not consistent with State speed limit statutes. 1970-72 Op. Atty. Gen. 303. (Decided under prior law.)

3. Amendment by Legislature.

The Legislature may amend town charters even though this section does not contemplate such amendment; and the Legislature may even amend or repeal this section itself. 1970-72 Op. Atty. Gen. 303. (Decided under prior law.)

Cited. Kirchner v. Giebink, 150 Vt. 172, 552 A.2d 372 (1988); Smith v. Town of St. Johnsbury, 150 Vt. 351, 554 A.2d 233 (1988).

4. Construction.

It can be fairly and reasonably inferred from the statute governing town charters and the Town of Brattleboro's charter that the selectboard may comment in good faith on proposed charter amendments, even if voter-initiated, concerning town operations or functions. Daims v. Town of Brattleboro, 202 Vt. 276, 148 A.3d 185 (2016).

§ 2646. Town officers; qualification; election.

At the annual meeting, a town shall choose from among its registered voters the following town officers, who shall serve until the next annual meeting and until successors are chosen, unless otherwise provided by law:

  1. A moderator.
  2. A town clerk, unless the town has voted to authorize the selectboard to appoint the town clerk as provided in section 2651e of this chapter. The term of office for a town clerk shall be for one year, unless a town votes that the clerk shall be elected for a term of three years. When a town votes for a three-year term for the office of town clerk, that three-year term shall remain in effect until the town rescinds it by the majority vote of the legal voters present and voting at an annual meeting, duly warned for that purpose.
  3. A town treasurer, unless the town has voted to authorize the selectboard to appoint the treasurer as provided in section 2651f of this chapter. The term of office of a town treasurer shall be for one year, unless a town votes that a town treasurer shall be elected for a term of three years. When a town votes for a three-year term for the office of town treasurer, that three-year term shall remain in effect until the town rescinds it by the majority vote of the legal voters present and voting at an annual meeting, duly warned for that purpose.
  4. One selectboard member for a term of three years who shall be elected by ballot.
  5. One lister for a term of three years who shall be elected by ballot, unless the town has voted to eliminate the office of lister in accordance with the provisions of section 2651c of this chapter.
  6. One auditor for the term of three years who shall be elected by ballot, unless the town has voted to eliminate the office of auditor in accordance with the provisions of section 2651b of this chapter.
  7. A first constable, and if needed a second constable, unless the town has voted to authorize the selectboard to appoint constables as provided in section 2651a of this chapter. The terms of office of the first and second constable elected or appointed shall be for one year unless a town votes that they shall be elected or appointed for terms of two years. When a town votes for a two-year term for the offices of first and second constable, the two-year terms shall remain in effect until the town rescinds them by a majority vote of the legal voters voting at an annual meeting, duly warned for that purpose.
  8. [Repealed.]
  9. A collector of delinquent taxes, if the town so votes, for a term of one year unless a town votes that a collector of delinquent taxes shall be elected for a term of three years. When a town votes for a three-year term for the collector of delinquent taxes, that three-year term shall remain in effect until the town rescinds it by the majority vote of the legal voters present and voting at an annual meeting, duly warned for that purpose.
  10. [Repealed.]
  11. [Repealed.]
  12. A trustee of public funds if the town so votes.
  13. A trustee of public money, but only in towns that retain possession of a portion of the surplus funds of the United States received under the Act of 1836.
  14. A cemetery commissioner if the town so votes.
  15. One or more patrol officers to patrol town highways under the direction of the selectboard, if the town so votes.
  16. One or two road commissioners who shall be elected by ballot if the town so votes; otherwise they shall be appointed by the selectboard as provided in section 2651 of this chapter. The road commissioners shall be elected for a term of one year unless a town votes that the commissioners shall be elected for a term of two or three years. When a town votes for a two-year or three-year term for the office of road commissioner, that two-year or three-year term shall remain in effect until the town rescinds it by the majority vote of the legal voters present and voting at an annual meeting, duly warned for that purpose.
  17. Three water commissioners, unless the town votes to elect additional selectboard members, in which case the number of water commissioners shall, at the discretion of the selectboard members, be the same as the number of members that comprise the selectboard. The commissioners shall be elected by ballot if the town so votes; otherwise they shall be appointed by the selectboard as provided in section 2651 of this chapter.
  18. Five members of an advisory budget committee, if the town so votes, unless the town votes to elect additional advisory budget committee members. The advisory budget committee members shall be elected by ballot, unless the town votes to have those members appointed by the selectboard.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1983, No. 218 (Adj. Sess.); 1991, No. 177 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; 1997, No. 83 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; 1999, No. 22, § 1; 1999, No. 73 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; 2001, No. 3, § 1; 2013, No. 21, § 1; 2013, No. 106 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; 2013, No. 161 (Adj. Sess.), § 48; 2013, No. 162 (Adj. Sess.), § 5; 2017, No. 27, § 1, eff. May 10, 2017; 2017, No. 93 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; 2019, No. 84 (Adj. Sess.), § 1.

History

Amendments--2019 (Adj. Sess.). Subdiv. (11): Repealed.

Amendments--2017 (Adj. Sess.). Subdiv. (10): Repealed.

Amendments--2017. Subdivs. (2), (3): Amended generally.

Amendments--2013 (Adj. Sess.). Act No. 106 substituted "votes" for "orders" and "ordered" throughout the section, deleted "has" following "town" in subdivs. (12), (14), (16), (17), and added subdiv. (18).

Introductory paragraph: Act No. 161 substituted "registered" for "legally qualified" following "choose from among its".

Subdiv. (8): Repealed by Act No. 162.

Amendments--2013. Subdiv. (4): Substituted "selectboard" for "selectman".

Subdiv. (5): Inserted ", unless the town has voted to eliminate the office of lister in accordance with the provisions of section 2651c of this chapter" following "ballot".

Subdiv. (6): Substituted "chapter" for "title" at the end of the subdivision.

Subdiv. (7): Substituted "selectboard" for "selectmen" and "chapter" for "title".

Subdiv. (15): Substituted "patrol officers" for "patrolmen" and "selectboard" for "selectmen".

Subdiv. (16): Substituted "selectboard" for "selectmen" and "chapter" for "title".

Subdiv. (17): Substituted "chapter" for "title" at the end of the second sentence.

Amendments--2001. Subdiv. (9): Added "for a term of one year unless a town votes that a collector of delinquent taxes shall be elected for a term of three years" at the end of the first sentence and added the second sentence.

Amendments--1999 (Adj. Sess.). Subdiv. (16): Added the second and third sentences.

Amendments--1999. Subdiv. (17): Amended generally.

Amendments--1997 (Adj. Sess.). Subdiv. (6): Added the language beginning "unless".

Amendments--1991 (Adj. Sess.) Rewrote the former first sentence as the first and second sentences.

Amendments--1983 (Adj. Sess.) Subdiv. (7): Added the second sentence and "for terms of one year unless a town votes that they shall be elected for terms of two years" following "second constable" in the first sentence.

Effect of act; previous town orders. 2013, No. 106 (Adj. Sess.), § 3 provides: "A town that has ordered the election of officers under the provisions of 17 V.S.A. § 2646 prior to the effective date of Sec. 1 [July 1, 2014] of this act may continue to elect those officers after the effective date of Sec. 1 of this act."

ANNOTATIONS

Analysis

  • 1.Prior law.
  • 2.Construction.
  • 3.Town agent.
1. Prior law.

For decisions under prior provisions relating to the subject matter of this section, see annotations under former § 724 of this title.

2. Construction.

Provisions that certain enumerated officers shall be chosen are positive legislative commands, and voters may not decide when or how often they shall hold an election. Jenney v. Alden, 79 Vt. 156, 64 A. 609 (1906). (Decided under prior law.)

3. Town agent.

Town agent to prosecute and defend suits has no authority to settle a suit brought to recover damages for injuries occasioned by insufficiencies of highways, and make promise to pay damages that would be binding on town. Clay v. Wright, 44 Vt. 538 (1872). (Decided under prior law.)

In administration of that portion of criminal justice entrusted to towns, in which fine and costs collected go to town, and which is conducted at expense of town, necessity for legal advice and assistance in many cases is obvious and authority to employ counsel in such cases is lodged in town grand juror and not in town agent. Burton v. Inhabitants of Norwich, 34 Vt. 345 (1861). (Decided under prior law.)

When town agent employs an attorney in suit in favor of or against town, town is legally holden to pay for attorney's services without express vote to that effect; and rule is same, if town agent, being himself an attorney, renders professional services for town. Langdon v. Castleton, 30 Vt. 285 (1858). (Decided under prior law.)

If town agent, who is also an attorney, continues, after his term of office has expired, in the management of suits in which town is interested, without any objection from, or any express employment by town or his successor, he is entitled to recover of town for professional services rendered after his term of office as town agent has expired. Langdon v. Castleton, 30 Vt. 285 (1858). (Decided under prior law.)

Cited. State v. Hart, 149 Vt. 104, 539 A.2d 551 (1987).

§ 2647. Incompatible offices.

    1. An auditor shall not be town clerk, town treasurer, selectboard member, first constable, collector of current or delinquent taxes, trustee of public funds, town manager, road commissioner, water commissioner, sewage system commissioner, sewage disposal commissioner, cemetery commissioner, or town school district director; nor shall a spouse of or any person assisting any of these officers in the discharge of official duties be eligible to hold office as auditor. (a) (1) An auditor shall not be town clerk, town treasurer, selectboard member, first constable, collector of current or delinquent taxes, trustee of public funds, town manager, road commissioner, water commissioner, sewage system commissioner, sewage disposal commissioner, cemetery commissioner, or town school district director; nor shall a spouse of or any person assisting any of these officers in the discharge of official duties be eligible to hold office as auditor.
      1. A selectboard member or school director shall not be first constable, collector of taxes, town treasurer, assistant town treasurer, auditor, or town agent. (2) (A) A selectboard member or school director shall not be first constable, collector of taxes, town treasurer, assistant town treasurer, auditor, or town agent.
    3. A cemetery commissioner or library trustee shall not be town treasurer, assistant town treasurer, or auditor.
    4. A town manager shall not hold any elective office in that town or town school district.
    5. Election officers at local elections shall be disqualified as provided in section 2456 of this title.
  2. Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, if a school district prepares and reports its budget independently from the budget of the town and the school district is audited by an independent public accountant, a school director or spouse of a school director shall be eligible to hold office as auditor, town treasurer, or assistant town treasurer.
