A selectboard member shall not be lister or assessor.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1985, No. 196 (Adj. Sess.), § 6; 1993, No. 91, § 2; 2009, No. 44, § 5, eff. May 21, 2009; 2013, No. 21, § 2; 2013, No. 162 (Adj. Sess.), § 7; 2017, No. 130 (Adj. Sess.), § 7; 2019, No. 14, § 47, eff. April 30, 2019; 2019, No. 67, § 19, eff. June 17, 2019; 2019, No. 117 (Adj. Sess.), § 1, eff. June 23, 2020.

History

Amendments--2019 (Adj. Sess.). Subdiv. (a)(2): Added the subdiv. (A) and (B) designations.

Subsec. (b): Deleted "or" following "auditor" and inserted ", or assistant town treasurer" at the end.

Amendments--2019 Subdiv. (a)(1): Act No. 14 substituted "town school district director" for "town district school director".

Subsec. (b): Act No. 67 substituted "school director or spouse of a school director" for "person" preceding "shall be eligible" and "or town treasurer" for "even if that person's spouse holds office as a school director" following "auditor".

Amendments--2017 (Adj. Sess.). Subdivs. (a)(2) through (a)(4): Amended generally.

Amendments--2013 (Adj. Sess.). Subdiv. (a)(1): Inserted "cemetery commissioner," following "sewage disposal commissioner,".

Subdiv. (a)(3): Added, and redesignated the remaining subdivs. accordingly.

Amendments--2013. Subsec. (a): Added the subdiv. (1)-(4) designations and substituted "selectboard member" for "selectman" throughout the subsection.

Subdiv. (a)(2): Inserted "or assessor" following "lister".

Amendments--2009. Subsec. (a): Added the subsection designation and deleted "their" preceding "official".

Subsec. (b): Added.

Amendments--1993. Inserted "water commissioner, sewage system commissioner, sewage disposal commissioner" following "road commissioner" in the first sentence.

Amendments--1983. Deleted "lister" preceding "auditor" in the second sentence and added the third sentence.

Law review commentaries

Law review. For note, "A Crisis in Confidence: Municipal Officials Under Fire," see 16 Vt. L. Rev. 579 (1992).

§ 2648. Exceptions.

Section 2647 of this title shall not apply to towns having not more than 25 legal voters, but in these towns an auditor shall not audit his or her own accounts kept and rendered in some other official capacity, nor shall the husband or wife of any town official audit his or her spouse's official accounts.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1.

§ 2649. Number of officers.

    1. Each town shall have: (a) (1) Each town shall have:
      1. three selectboard members, unless additional selectboard members are elected under the provisions of section 2650 of this chapter;
      2. three listers, unless additional listers are elected under the provisions of section 2650 of this chapter or the town has voted to eliminate the office of lister under the provisions of section 2651c of this chapter; and
      3. three auditors, unless the town has voted to eliminate the office of auditor under the provisions of section 2651b of this chapter.
    2. Except as otherwise provided, at each annual meeting, one selectboard member, one lister, and one auditor shall be elected, each for a term of three years.
  2. A town so voting may elect one or two road commissioners for a term of one, two, or three years, as provided in section 2646 of this chapter.
  3. A town so voting may elect three water commissioners. The terms of the water commissioners shall be the same as those of selectboard members under sections 2646 and 2650 of this chapter, except that of those commissioners first elected, one shall have a term of one year, one a term of two years, and one a term of three years. One or two additional water commissioners may be authorized for one- or two-year terms as provided in subsection 2650(b) of this chapter relating to additional selectboard members.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1999, No. 73 (Adj. Sess.), § 2; amended 2013, No. 21, § 3.

History

Revision note. Reference to section 2647 in the next to last sentence changed to section 2646 to correct an apparent error in the reference.

Amendments--2013. Section amended generally.

Amendments--1999 (Adj. Sess.). Substituted "two, or three years, as provided in section 2646 of this title" for "year" at the end of the third sentence.

Towns excluded; additional selectboard members or listers. 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 3, provided: "Towns having already elected more than three selectmen or three listers prior to the effective date of this act [July 1, 1978] are excepted from the initial application of section 2649 [this section]."

Cross References

Cross references. Appointment of road and water commissioners, see § 2651 of this chapter.

Submission of question of election of road and water commissioners to voters, see § 2652 of this chapter.

ANNOTATIONS

Analysis

  • 1.Construction with other laws.
  • 2.Listers.
1. Construction with other laws.

It was intent of Legislature, under this section and former 24 V.S.A. § 871, that selectboard members should and can function as a board and that in most instances they must so function in order that their acts may have force. State v. Baldwin, 116 Vt. 112, 70 A.2d 242 (1950). (Decided under prior law.)

2. Listers.

Towns are required by statute to elect annually three, four, or five listers who constitute a board, a majority of which is essential to legal action; and hence, an indictment, charging lister with perjury in that he violated his official oath, was defective without allegation of election of requisite number of listers, and that they qualified and acted as such. State v. Peters, 57 Vt. 86 (1884). (Decided under prior law.)

§ 2650. Additional listers and selectboard members.

  1. Additional listers. A town may vote at a special or annual town meeting to elect two additional listers for terms of one year each.
  2. Additional selectboard members.
      1. A town may vote at a special or annual town meeting to elect two additional selectboard members for terms of either one or two years each. (1) (A) A town may vote at a special or annual town meeting to elect two additional selectboard members for terms of either one or two years each.
      2. When the terms of the additional selectboard members are to be for two years, the warning for the meeting shall so specify.
      1. If two additional selectboard member positions are created, they shall be for terms of the same length, but if the terms of the new positions are to be for two years, when the additional selectboard members are first elected, one shall be elected for one year and the other selectboard member for two years. (2) (A) If two additional selectboard member positions are created, they shall be for terms of the same length, but if the terms of the new positions are to be for two years, when the additional selectboard members are first elected, one shall be elected for one year and the other selectboard member for two years.
      2. Terms of these additional selectboard members shall end on annual meeting days. If the additional selectboard members are elected at a special meeting, the term of those elected for one year shall expire on the next annual meeting day and those elected for two years shall expire on the second annual meeting day following their election.
  3. Discontinuing additional listers or selectboard members.
    1. A vote establishing additional listers or selectboard members shall remain in effect until the town votes to discontinue the two additional positions at an annual or special meeting duly warned for that purpose.
    2. The term of office of any lister or selectboard member in office on the date a town votes to discontinue that office shall expire on the 31st day after the vote, unless a petition for reconsideration or rescission of that vote is filed with the clerk of the municipality in accordance with section 2661 of this chapter, in which case that section shall control.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 2017, No. 50, § 50.

History

Amendments--2017. Section amended generally.

§ 2651. Road and water commissioners; appointment, removal.

  1. Unless the town votes to elect road commissioners, the selectboard shall appoint forthwith one or two road commissioners and may remove from office a road commissioner appointed by them, for just cause after due notice and hearing. The selectboard may appoint one or two members of their own board to serve as road commissioners.
  2. Unless the town votes to elect water commissioners, the selectboard shall appoint forthwith no less than three nor more than five water commissioners, unless there is no existing, or prospective, municipal water system for such commissioners to supervise. The selectboard may remove an appointed water commissioner from office for just cause after due notice and hearing. The selectboard may appoint members of their own board to serve as water commissioners.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1999, No. 22, § 2.

History

2018. In subsec. (a), substituted "selectboard" for "selectmen" twice in accordance with 2013, No. 161 (Adj. Sess.), § 72.

Amendments--1999. Subsec. (b): Amended generally.

Cross References

Cross references. Election of road and water commissioners generally, see § 2646 of this chapter.

Terms of office of road and water commissioners, see § 2649 of this chapter.

§ 2651a. Constables; appointment; removal.

    1. A town may vote by Australian ballot at an annual meeting to authorize the selectboard to appoint a first constable, and if needed a second constable, in which case at least a first constable shall be appointed. (a) (1) A town may vote by Australian ballot at an annual meeting to authorize the selectboard to appoint a first constable, and if needed a second constable, in which case at least a first constable shall be appointed.
    2. A constable so appointed may be removed by the selectboard for just cause after notice and hearing.
    3. When a town votes to authorize the selectboard to appoint constables, the selectboard's authority to make such appointments shall remain in effect until the town rescinds that authority by the majority vote of the registered voters present and voting at an annual meeting, duly warned for that purpose.
  2. Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) to the contrary, a vote to authorize the selectboard to appoint constables shall become effective only upon a two-thirds vote of those present and voting, if a written protest against the authorization is filed with the selectboard at least 15 days before the vote by at least five percent of the voters of the town.
  3. The authority to authorize the selectboard to appoint the constable as provided in this section shall extend to all towns except those that have a charter that specifically provides for the election or appointment of the office of constable.

Added 1991, No. 177 (Adj. Sess.), § 2; amended 2017, No. 130 (Adj. Sess.), § 1.

History

Amendments--2017 (Adj. Sess.). Section amended generally.

Cross References

Cross references. Authority of town to limit powers and qualifications of constables, see 24 V.S.A. § 1936a.

§ 2651b. Elimination of office of auditor; appointment of public accountant.

    1. A town may vote by ballot at an annual meeting to eliminate the office of town auditor. (a) (1) A town may vote by ballot at an annual meeting to eliminate the office of town auditor.
      1. If a town votes to eliminate the office of town auditor, the selectboard shall contract with a public accountant licensed in this State to perform an annual financial audit of all funds of the town except the funds audited pursuant to 16 V.S.A. § 323. (2) (A) If a town votes to eliminate the office of town auditor, the selectboard shall contract with a public accountant licensed in this State to perform an annual financial audit of all funds of the town except the funds audited pursuant to 16 V.S.A. § 323.
      2. Unless otherwise provided by law, the selectboard shall provide for all other auditor's duties to be performed.
    3. A vote to eliminate the office of town auditor shall remain in effect until rescinded by majority vote of the registered voters present and voting, by ballot, at an annual meeting duly warned for that purpose.
  2. The term of office of any auditor in office on the date a town votes to eliminate that office shall expire on the 45th day after such vote or on the date upon which the selectboard enters into a contract with a public accountant under this section, whichever occurs first.
  3. The authority to vote to eliminate the office of town auditor as provided in this section shall extend to all towns except those towns that have a charter that specifically provides for the election or appointment of the office of town auditor.

Added 1997, No. 83 (Adj. Sess.), § 2; amended 2011, No. 129 (Adj. Sess.), § 28, eff. July 1, 2013; amended 2013, No. 21, § 3a; 2017, No. 130 (Adj. Sess.), § 2.

History

Amendments--2017 (Adj. Sess.) Subsec. (a): Added the subdiv. (a)(1), (a)(2)(A), (a)(2)(B), and (a)(3) designations, substituted "auditor's" for "auditor" in subdiv. (a)(2)(B), and substituted "registered" for "legal" in subdiv. (a)(3).

Amendments--2013. Subsec. (c): Added.

Amendments--2011 (Adj. Sess.) Subsec. (a): Added "except the funds audited pursuant to 16 V.S.A. § 323" at the end of the second sentence.

§ 2651c. Lack of elected lister; appointment of lister; elimination of office.

    1. Notwithstanding any other provisions of law to the contrary and except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, in the event the board of listers of a town falls below a majority and the selectboard is unable to find a person or persons to appoint as a lister or listers under the provisions of 24 V.S.A. § 963, the selectboard may appoint an assessor to perform the duties of a lister as set forth in Title 32 until the next annual meeting. (a) (1) Notwithstanding any other provisions of law to the contrary and except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, in the event the board of listers of a town falls below a majority and the selectboard is unable to find a person or persons to appoint as a lister or listers under the provisions of 24 V.S.A. § 963, the selectboard may appoint an assessor to perform the duties of a lister as set forth in Title 32 until the next annual meeting.
    2. The appointed person need not be a resident of the town and shall have the same powers and be subject to the same duties and penalties as a duly elected lister for the town.
    1. A town may vote by ballot at an annual meeting to eliminate the office of lister. (b) (1) A town may vote by ballot at an annual meeting to eliminate the office of lister.
      1. If a town votes to eliminate the office of lister, the selectboard shall contract with or employ a professionally qualified assessor, who need not be a resident of the town. (2) (A) If a town votes to eliminate the office of lister, the selectboard shall contract with or employ a professionally qualified assessor, who need not be a resident of the town.
      2. The assessor shall have the same powers, discharge the same duties, proceed in the discharge thereof in the same manner, and be subject to the same liabilities as are prescribed for listers or the board of listers under the provisions of Title 32.
    3. A vote to eliminate the office of lister shall remain in effect until rescinded by majority vote of the registered voters present and voting at an annual meeting warned for that purpose.
  3. The term of office of any lister in office on the date a town votes to eliminate that office shall expire on the 45th day after the vote or on the date upon which the selectboard appoints an assessor under this subsection, whichever occurs first.
  4. The authority to vote to eliminate the office of lister as provided in this section shall extend to all towns except those towns that have a charter that specifically provides for the election or appointment of the office of lister.

Added 2003, No. 125 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 2013, No. 21, § 4; 2017, No. 130 (Adj. Sess.), § 3.

History

Amendments--2017 (Adj. Sess.). Section amended generally.

Amendments--2013. Added "of lister; elimination of office" to the section catchline and the subsec. (a) designation; inserted "and except as provided in subsection (b) of this section" following "contrary"; and "under the provisions of 24 V.S.A. § 963" following "a lister or listers" in subsec. (a) and added subsec. (b).

§ 2651d. Collector of delinquent taxes; appointment; removal.

    1. A municipality may vote at an annual or special municipal meeting to authorize the legislative body to appoint a collector of delinquent taxes, who may be the municipal treasurer. (a) (1) A municipality may vote at an annual or special municipal meeting to authorize the legislative body to appoint a collector of delinquent taxes, who may be the municipal treasurer.
    2. A collector of delinquent taxes so appointed may be removed by the legislative body for just cause after notice and hearing.
  2. When a municipality votes to authorize the legislative body to appoint a collector of delinquent taxes, the legislative body's authority to make such appointment shall remain in effect until the municipality rescinds that authority by the majority vote of the registered voters present and voting at an annual or special meeting, duly warned for that purpose.

Added 2013, No. 162 (Adj. Sess.), § 6; amended 2017, No. 130 (Adj. Sess.), § 4.

History

Amendments--2017 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (a): Added the subdiv. (1) and (2) designations and in subdiv. (a)(1), inserted "municipal" following "annual or special"..

Subsec. (b): Substituted "registered" for "legal" preceding "voters".

§ 2651e. Municipal clerk; appointment; removal.

    1. A municipality may vote at an annual meeting to authorize the legislative body to appoint the municipal clerk. (a) (1) A municipality may vote at an annual meeting to authorize the legislative body to appoint the municipal clerk.
    2. A municipal clerk so appointed may be removed by the legislative body for just cause after notice and hearing.
  2. A vote to authorize the legislative body to appoint the municipal clerk shall remain in effect until rescinded by the majority vote of the registered voters present and voting at an annual or special meeting, duly warned for that purpose.
  3. The term of office of a municipal clerk in office on the date a municipality votes to allow the legislative body to appoint a municipal clerk shall expire 45 calendar days after the vote or on the date upon which the legislative body appoints a municipal clerk under this section, whichever occurs first, unless a petition for reconsideration or rescission is filed in accordance with section 2661 of this title.
  4. The authority to authorize the legislative body to appoint the municipal clerk as provided in this section shall extend to all municipalities except those that have a charter that specifically provides for the election or appointment of the office of municipal clerk.

Added 2017, No. 27, § 2, eff. May 10, 2017; amended 2017, No. 130 (Adj. Sess.), § 5.

History

Amendments--2017 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (a): Added the subdiv. (1) and (2) designations.

Subsec. (b): Substituted "registered" for "legal" preceding "voters".

§ 2651f. Municipal treasurer; appointment; removal.

    1. A municipality may vote at an annual meeting to authorize the legislative body to appoint the municipal treasurer. (a) (1) A municipality may vote at an annual meeting to authorize the legislative body to appoint the municipal treasurer.
    2. A treasurer so appointed may be removed by the legislative body for just cause after notice and hearing.
  2. A vote to authorize the legislative body to appoint the treasurer shall remain in effect until rescinded by the majority vote of the registered voters present and voting at an annual or special meeting, duly warned for that purpose.
  3. The term of office of a treasurer in office on the date a municipality votes to allow the legislative body to appoint a treasurer shall expire 45 calendar days after the vote or on the date upon which the legislative body appoints a treasurer under this section, whichever occurs first, unless a petition for reconsideration or rescission is filed in accordance with section 2661 of this title.
  4. The authority to authorize the legislative body to appoint the treasurer as provided in this section shall extend to all municipalities except those that have a charter that specifically provides for the election or appointment of the office of municipal treasurer.

Added 2017, No. 27, § 3, eff. May 10, amended 2017; 2017, No. 130 (Adj. Sess.), § 6.

History

Amendments--2017 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (a): Added the subdiv. (1) and (2) designations.

Subsec. (b): Substituted "registered" for "legal" preceding "voters".

§ 2652. Road and water commissioners.

The selectboard may and, when requested by at least five percent of the legal voters of a town at least 47 days prior to the annual town meeting, it shall insert in the warning for the annual town meeting an article on the question of whether the town shall elect a road commissioner or commissioners, or water commissioners, as provided in section 2651 of this chapter.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 2017, No. 50, § 51.

History

Amendments--2017. Substituted "selectboard" for "board of selectmen"; substituted "47 days" for "40 days"; substituted "it" for "they" preceding "shall insert"; deleted "or not" following "whether"; and substituted "chapter" for "title".

Cross References

Cross references. Election of road and water commissioners generally, see § 2646 of this chapter.

Terms of office of road and water commissioners, see § 2649 of this chapter.

§ 2653. Acceptance of office.

A person present at the meeting electing him or her to municipal office shall be treated as accepting, unless he or she declines before the meeting is adjourned. When not present, he or she shall be served as soon as possible with a written notice, signed by the clerk and served by the constable.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1.

§ 2654. Refusal to serve.

A person may refuse to accept election or appointment to any municipal office.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1.

§ 2655. Time of meeting.

Annual municipal business meetings shall begin at the time set by the legislative body, unless the municipality has voted otherwise at a preceding meeting.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1979, No. 200 (Adj. Sess.), § 101.

History

Amendments--1979 (Adj. Sess.). Section amended generally.

§ 2656. Qualification and registration of voters.

Regardless of the type of voting used, the qualifications to vote in any municipal election shall be as provided in chapter 43 of this title and all municipalities shall revise and post checklists as provided in chapter 43 of this title prior to any municipal meeting at which there will be voting. The presiding officer shall follow reasonable and necessary procedures to ensure that persons who are not voters of the town do not vote.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1979, No. 200 (Adj. Sess.), § 102.

History

Amendments--1979 (Adj. Sess.). Substituted "voting" for "balloting" preceding "used" and "revise and post" for "post and revise" preceding "checklists" in the first sentence and added the last sentence.

ANNOTATIONS

1. Prior law.

For decisions under prior provisions relating to the subject matter of this section, see annotations under former §§ 241 and 246 of this title.

§ 2657. Moderator.

A municipal meeting shall be called to order by the moderator, or in his or her absence by a selectboard member who shall preside until a moderator pro tempore is chosen.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1.

History

2018. Substituted "selectboard member" for "selectmen" in accordance with 2013, No. 161 (Adj. Sess.), § 72.

ANNOTATIONS

1. Ratification.

Where moderator elected at annual town meeting was called without another election to preside at another meeting warned and held during year, action of meeting was valid, when he was allowed to preside without objection on that score on the part of the voters, and the meeting proceeded to completion of business for which it was warned. State v. Vershire, 52 Vt. 41 (1879). (Decided under prior law.)

§ 2658. Duties.

The moderator shall be the presiding officer of municipal meetings, shall decide questions of order and shall make public declaration of votes taken, except in elections using the Australian ballot system. When a vote declared by him or her is immediately questioned by one voter, he or she shall divide the meeting, and if requested by seven voters, shall cause the vote to be taken by paper ballot, unless the town has provided some other procedure in such cases. Robert's Rules or some other rules of order shall govern all municipal meetings, except in elections using the Australian ballot system.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1979, No. 200 (Adj. Sess.), § 103; 1981, No. 239 (Adj. Sess.), § 23.

History

Amendments--1981 (Adj. Sess.). Added the last sentence.

Amendments--1979 (Adj. Sess.). Added "except in elections using the Australian ballot system" following "votes taken" at the end of the first sentence.

ANNOTATIONS

1. Generally.

The moderator of town meeting is under no duty to invite open discussion at meetings; his duties, under this section, are to decide questions of order and make public declaration of votes passed. Groton v. Union School Dist. 21, 127 Vt. 142, 241 A.2d 332 (1968). (Decided under prior law.)

§ 2659. Preservation of order.

The moderator shall preserve order in the conduct of business and in debate. If a person, after notice, is persistently disorderly and refuses to withdraw from the meeting, the moderator may cause him or her to be removed, calling upon the constable or other person for that purpose. A person who so refuses to withdraw when ordered so to do shall be fined not more than $200.00.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1.

§ 2660. Conduct of election.

  1. When voting is at a floor meeting by paper ballot, the polls shall be kept open a reasonable time and reasonable notice shall be given before they close.
  2. When election is by ballot, a majority of all votes cast for any office shall be required for an election, unless otherwise provided by law; provided that when there is but one nominee for an office, unless objection is made, the legal voters may vote to instruct the town clerk to cast one ballot for such nominee and upon such ballot being cast he or she shall be declared elected.
  3. If no person has obtained a majority by the end of the third vote, the moderator shall announce that the person receiving the least number of votes in the last vote and in each succeeding vote shall no longer be a candidate, and the voting shall continue until a candidate receives a majority.
  4. The article entitled "other business" shall not be used for taking binding municipal action, and the moderator shall so rule.

Added 1977, No. 260 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1979, No. 200 (Adj. Sess.), § 104; 2013, No. 161 (Adj. Sess.), § 49.

History

Amendments--2013 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (a): Substituted "When voting is at a floor meeting by paper ballot" for "When voting is by ballot" at the beginning.

Subsec. (b): Inserted "or she" following "ballot being cast he".

Amendments--1979 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (d): Added.

§ 2661. Reconsideration or rescission of vote.

  1. A warned article voted on at an annual or special meeting of a municipality shall not be submitted to the voters for reconsideration or rescission at the same meeting after the assembly has begun consideration of another article. If the voters have begun consideration of another article, the original article may only be submitted to the voters at a subsequent annual or special meeting duly warned for the purpose and called by the legislative body on its own motion or pursuant to a petition requesting such reconsideration or rescission signed and submitted in accordance with subsection (b) of this section. A vote taken at an annual or special meeting shall remain in effect unless rescinded or amended.
  2. If a petition requesting reconsideration or rescission of a question considered or voted on at a previous annual or special meeting is filed with the clerk of the municipality within 30 days following the date of that meeting, the legislative body shall provide for a vote by the municipality in accordance with the petition within 60 days of the submission at an annual or special meeting duly warned for that purpose. The number of signatures required for a petition for reconsideration or rescission shall be not less than five percent of the registered voters unless the voters of the municipality increase that percentage pursuant to the following:
    1. At a meeting duly warned for the purpose, the voters of a municipality may require that a petition for reconsideration be signed by a percentage of registered voters that is not less than five percent nor greater than 20 percent.
    2. A vote to increase the percentage of voters required to sign a petition for reconsideration or rescission to up to 20 percent shall be in substantially the following form: "Shall the (name of municipality) increase the percentage of voters required on a petition for reconsideration or rescission from five to (up to 20) percent?"
    3. Once the voters of a municipality have voted to require a new percentage, that percentage shall remain in effect until the voters of the municipality vote to change the percentage.
  3. A question voted on shall not be presented for reconsideration or rescission at more than one subsequent meeting within a one-year period, except with the approval of the legislative body.
  4. For a vote by Australian ballot:
    1. The form of the ballot shall be as follows: "Article 1: [cite the article to be reconsidered as lastly voted]."
    2. Absentee ballots for the reconsideration or rescission vote shall be sent to any voter who requested an absentee ballot for the initial vote on the article to be reconsidered or rescinded, whether or not a separate request for an absentee ballot for the reconsideration or rescission vote is submitted by the voter.
  5. A majority vote in favor of reconsideration or rescission of a question voted on by paper or Australian ballot shall not be effective unless the number of votes cast in favor of reconsideration or rescission exceeds two-thirds of the number of votes cast for the prevailing side at the original meeting unless the voters of the municipality approve a different percentage pursuant to the following:
    1. At a meeting duly warned for the purpose, the voters of a municipality may require that a vote in favor of reconsideration or rescission shall not be effective unless the number of votes cast in favor of reconsideration or rescission exceeds a certain percentage of the number of votes cast for the prevailing side at the original meeting.
    2. A vote to increase or decrease the percentage shall be in substantially the following form: "Shall the (name of municipality) change the percentage of votes cast in favor of reconsideration or rescission required for a vote to reconsider or rescind a question considered or voted on at a previous annual or special meeting to be effective to (percentage)?"
    3. Once the voters of a municipality have voted to require a new percentage, that percentage shall remain in effect until the voters of the municipality vote to change the percentage.
  6. A municipality shall not reconsider a vote to elect a local officer.
  7. This section shall not apply to nonbinding advisory articles, which shall not be subject to reconsideration or rescission.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1979, No. 200 (Adj. Sess.), § 105; 1991, No. 235 (Adj. Sess.); 2007, No. 36, § 1; 2013, No. 161 (Adj. Sess.), § 50; 2017, No. 50, § 52.

History

Amendments--2017. Subsec. (c): Substituted "a one-year period," for "the succeeding 12 months".

Subsec. (d): Added the subdiv. (1) designation and subdiv. (2).

Subsec. (g): Added.

Amendments--2013 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (f): Added.

Amendments--2007. Subsec. (b): Amended generally.

Subsec. (e): Added.

Amendments--1991 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (a): Added "after the assembly has begun consideration of another article" following "same meeting" in the first sentence, substituted "If the voters have begun consideration of another article, the original article" for "It" at the beginning of the second sentence and added "or amended" following "rescinded" in the third sentence.

Subsec. (c): Inserted "within the succeeding twelve months" preceding "except".

Subsec. (d): Added.

Amendments--1979 (Adj. Sess.). Section amended generally.

Vote for reconsideration or rescission. 2007, No. 36, § 2, provides: "This act shall take effect on July 1, 2007. However, in Sec. 1 [which amended this section]; 17 V.S.A. § 2661(e) shall apply to a vote for reconsideration or rescission for which a petition has been filed on or after July 1, 2008".

ANNOTATIONS

Analysis

  • 1.Warnings.
  • 2.Ballot.
  • 3.Question voted on.
  • 4.Reconsideration.
1. Warnings.

Warning for special town meeting to discuss proposed amendments to zoning bylaws that were identical to or substantially similar to changes approved by vote of the electors at an earlier town meeting, the results of which were subsequently declared invalid because of procedural irregularities in a judicial proceeding, was not violative of the notice requirements of 24 V.S.A. § 4404 because it did not instead call for reconsideration or rescission of the vote at the earlier meeting, since the earlier vote, because not taken in accordance with the prescribed statutory procedures, was void ab initio and, therefore, there was nothing to re-evaluate. Kalakowski v. Town of Clarendon, 139 Vt. 519, 431 A.2d 478 (1981).

2. Ballot.

Where, at town meeting, town voted to appropriate funds for and construct park, and statutory petition requesting a special town meeting for purpose of rescinding that vote resulted in a properly warned meeting at which the ballot stated the question was whether the town would vote to approve construction of the park and appropriate funds therefore, the ballot was not substantially in accord with the issue framed by the petition, as required by this section, and was contrary to provision of this section stating an annual town meeting vote shall remain in effect unless rescinded; and selectboard would be ordered to warn and hold a new meeting to vote on petition's question. Concerned Voters of Londonderry v. Prouty, 138 Vt. 442, 417 A.2d 927 (1980).

3. Question voted on.

Town voters were not entitled to a new reconsideration vote on school budget under 16 V.S.A. § 711e, which sets forth the procedure when a school district elects to have its budget determined by Australian ballot, because there had already been a reconsideration vote of the school budget at issue; the term "question voted on" in subsection (c) of this section means the budget of the school district and not the specific budget amount submitted to the voters and thus this section prevented further revotes without the approval of the legislative body of the district. Santi v. Roxbury Town School District, 165 Vt. 476, 685 A.2d 301 (1996).

Statute regarding reconsideration of votes at town meetings was designed to enable the voters of a town, upon securing the necessary signatures, to secure a vote to reconsider a matter previously acted upon by the voters. The goals of the statute would be frustrated by an interpretation that suggested that the right of voters to petition for reconsideration of a question turns on the parliamentary procedure by which the question was defeated in the first instance. Wesolow v. Town of Lowell, 19 Vt. 422, 90 A.3d 898 (2013).

4. Reconsideration.

Because the effect of town voters' motion to pass over an article was to effectively dismiss the article without further debate, their action amounted to consideration of or a vote on the article for purposes of the applicability of the statute regarding reconsideration of votes. Accordingly, a petition for reconsideration was appropriate. Wesolow v. Town of Lowell, 19 Vt. 422, 90 A.3d 898 (2013).

Cited. Cota v. Town School District of Starksboro, 144 Vt. 633, 481 A.2d 1267 (1984).

§ 2662. Validation of municipal meetings.

When any of the requirements as to notice or warning of an annual or special municipal meeting have been omitted or not complied with, the omission or noncompliance, if the meeting and the business transacted at it is otherwise legal and within the scope of the municipal powers, may be corrected and legalized by vote at a regular meeting or special meeting of the municipality called and duly warned for that purpose. The question to be voted upon shall substantially be, "Shall the action taken at the meeting of this town (or city, village or district) held on (state date) in spite of the fact that (state the error or omission), and any act or action of the municipal officers or agents pursuant thereto be readopted, ratified, and confirmed." Errors or omissions in the conduct of an original meeting that are not the result of an unlawful notice or warning or noncompliance within the scope of the warning may be cured by a resolution of the legislative body of the municipality by a vote of two-thirds of all its members at a regular meeting or a special meeting called for that purpose, stating that the defect was the result of oversight, inadvertence, or mistake. When an error or omission of this nature has been thus corrected by resolution, all business within the terms of the action of the qualified voters shall be as valid as if the requirements had been initially complied with, condition, however, that the original action thereby corrected by the legislative body was in compliance with the legal exercise of its corporate powers.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1.

ANNOTATIONS

Analysis

  • 1.Application.
  • 2.Record of meeting.
  • 3.Contents of warning.
  • 4.Sufficiency of warning.
1. Application.

Even if a defect was present in an organizational meeting for a union high school district, such defect could not have had any effect on status of the union as a "body politic," achieved before such meeting was held, and, in any event, procedures under this section were available to the district for necessary corrective purposes. Appelget & Elliott v. Baird, 126 Vt. 503, 236 A.2d 671 (1967). (Decided under prior law.)

Procedure set forth in this section should be followed when municipality seeks to correct mistake in procedure in course of voting bonds for public improvement. 1956-58 Op. Atty. Gen. 117. (Decided under prior law.)

2. Record of meeting.

Certified copy of proceedings of meeting, as kept and reported by clerk pro tem. to the town clerk, was admissible for purpose of showing vote of meeting. Hickok v. Shelburne, 41 Vt. 409 (1868). (Decided under prior law.)

3. Contents of warning.

Warning for validation meeting held because notice of annual school district meeting was not published as required by former 24 V.S.A. § 706p(a) did not have to state, and voters did not have to vote on, each article of the prior meeting separately, but rather, warning and vote could be on whether the action taken at the prior meeting and any action pursuant thereto should be readopted, ratified and confirmed. Brochu v. Brown, 128 Vt. 549, 268 A.2d 745 (1970). (Decided under prior law.)

4. Sufficiency of warning.

Validation meeting warning as to whether the action taken at annual school district meeting and any action taken pursuant thereto should be readopted, ratified and confirmed in spite of the fact that notice of the annual meeting was not published as required by former 24 V.S.A. § 706p(a) sufficiently indicated the purpose of the meeting. Brochu v. Brown, 128 Vt. 549, 268 A.2d 745 (1970). (Decided under prior law.)

Where particular property was voted a tax exemption at 1968 town meeting and the subject had not been in the warning for that meeting, article in warning for 1969 town meeting presenting question whether voters would ratify and reaffirm the 1968 vote, and affirmative vote, was adequate corrective action. Lawton v. Town of Brattleboro, 128 Vt. 525, 266 A.2d 816 (1970). (Decided under prior law.)

§ 2663. Certificate of vote.

Whenever an act of the General Assembly by its provisions takes effect only when accepted by vote of a municipality, the clerk of the municipality shall certify within 10 days to the Secretary of State the result of such vote.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1.

§ 2664. Budget.

At its annual meeting, a town shall vote such sums of money as it deems necessary for the interest of its inhabitants and for the prosecution and defense of the common rights. It shall express in its vote the specific amounts, or the rate on a dollar of the grand list, to be appropriated for laying out and repairing highways and for other necessary town expenses. If a town votes specific amounts in lieu of a rate on a dollar of the grand list, the selectboard shall, after the grand list book has been computed and lodged in the office of the town clerk, set the tax rate necessary to raise the specific amounts voted. The selectboard may apply for grants and may accept and expend grants or gifts above those that are approved in the town budget. The selectboard shall include, in its annual report, a description of all grants or gifts accepted during the year and associated expenditures.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 2007, No. 121 (Adj. Sess.), § 12; 2015, No. 30, § 25, eff. May 26, 2015.

History

Amendments--2015. Inserted "At its annual meeting" preceding "a town shall" in the first sentence.

Amendments--2007 (Adj. Sess.) Substituted "selectboard" for "selectmen" in the third sentence, and added the fourth and fifth sentences.

ANNOTATIONS

Analysis

  • 1.Construction.
  • 2.Taxation.
  • 3.Authority to bind town.
  • 4.Health.
  • 5.Public property.
  • 6.Legal proceedings.
1. Construction.

The rights and interests meant by this section are rights and interests of inhabitants in their corporate capacity; and statute does not authorize town to vote money to pay expenses incurred by some of its inhabitants in opposing act of Legislature constituting part of town's territory into new town and apportioning former's assets and liabilities between two. Sargent v. Clark, 83 Vt. 523, 77 A. 337 (1910). (Decided under prior law.)

Towns are creations of Legislature, are constituted for governmental purposes, and so rights and franchises of town never can become vested rights as against State, which may enlarge, restrict, and even destroy its corporate existence, as the public good requires; and such action neither defeats vested rights nor impairs contract obligations within the meaning of Constitution. Sargent v. Clark, 83 Vt. 523, 77 A. 337 (1910). (Decided under prior law.)

Inhabitants of town cannot impose tax or appropriate funds for objects entirely foreign to their political or municipal duties; but they may do so for objects within their duty and jurisdiction as municipal corporations, and for purpose of fully enabling them to discharge that duty. Van Sicklen v. Burlington, 27 Vt. 70 (1854). (Decided under prior law.)

2. Taxation.

A town may tax real estate within its boundaries based on its grand list. Porter v. Town of Newark, 145 Vt. 367, 488 A.2d 769 (1985).

3. Authority to bind town.

Selectboard cannot bind town by offer of reward for arrest and conviction of person guilty of removing body from its grave in cemetery in town, it not appearing that town's property was injured nor that any statute cast upon town burden of prosecuting such offenses. Spafford v. Norwich, 71 Vt. 78, 42 A. 970 (1898). (Decided under prior law.)

4. Health.

Selectboard of town, inhabitants of which are exposed to spreading of smallpox among them, may prevent such spread by procuring inoculation for those exposed, and town may legally vote tax to defray expense of same. Hazen v. Strong, 2 Vt. 427 (1830). (Decided under prior law.)

5. Public property.

If primary purpose of erection of a town house was for proper municipal uses, town may rent a part of it for income; and it rests in discretion of voters, exercised in good faith, to decide as to expense of such building and in so doing they may anticipate prospective needs of town. Bates v. Bassett, 60 Vt. 530, 15 A. 200 (1888). (Decided under prior law.)

6. Legal proceedings.

Officers of town cannot bind it for expense of carrying on suit in which it has no direct interest. Sheldon v. Bennington, 67 Vt. 580, 32 A. 497 (1895). (Decided under prior law.)

Town may vote tax to defend suit in which it is interested, whether it is directly for or against town, or between third persons. Briggs v. Whipple, 6 Vt. 95 (1834). (Decided under prior law.)

Cited. Addison County Community Action Group v. City of Vergennes, 152 Vt. 161, 565 A.2d 233 (1989).

§ 2665. Notification to Secretary of State.

The town clerk shall file with the Secretary of State a list of the names and addresses of the selectboard members elected and shall notify the Secretary of State of any changes in the list as filed.

Added 1979, No. 200 (Adj. Sess.), § 106.

History

2018. Substituted "selectboard members" for "selectmen" in accordance with 2013, No. 161 (Adj. Sess.), § 72.

§ 2666. Improper influence.

Neither the warning, the notice, the official voter information cards, nor the ballot itself shall include any opinion or comment by any town body or officer or other person on any matter to be voted on.

Added 1979, No. 200 (Adj. Sess.), § 107.

Cross References

Cross references. Election offenses generally, see chapter 35 of this title.

ANNOTATIONS

1. Construction.

School district did not improperly influence vote, in violation of 17 V.S.A. § 2666, by sending voters letter about issues to be voted upon where letter contained no opinion or comment on any of official documents listed in 17 V.S.A. § 2666. Conn v. Middlebury Union High School District #3, 162 Vt. 498, 648 A.2d 1385 (1994).

§ 2667. Access to annual meeting.

The legislative body of the municipality shall take reasonable measures to ensure that voters who are elders or have a disability may conveniently attend annual or special meetings; provided, however, that such measures need not be taken if doing so would impose undue hardship on the town. Measures may include location of meetings on the ground floor of buildings or providing ramps or other devices for access to meetings. In municipal elections using the Australian ballot system of voting, subsection 2502(b) of this title shall apply. For the purposes of this section, the legislative body shall have full jurisdiction on the day of the municipal meeting over the premises at which the town meeting is to be held.

Added 1983, No. 90, § 2, eff. April 29, 1983; amended 2013, No. 96 (Adj. Sess.), § 85.

History

Amendments--2013 (Adj. Sess.). Substituted "ensure" for "assure" following "measures to" and "voters who are elders or have a disability" for "elderly or handicapped voters" preceding "may conveniently" in the first sentence, deleted ", but are not limited to," following "Measures may include" in the second sentence, and inserted "of this title" following "2502(b)" in the last sentence.

Subchapter 3. Local Elections Using the Australian Ballot System

§ 2680. Australian ballot system; general.

  1. Application. Unless specifically required by statute, the provisions of the Australian ballot system shall not apply to the annual or special meeting of a municipality unless that municipality, at its annual meeting or at a special meeting called for that purpose, votes to have them apply.
  2. Officers. Once a municipality votes to elect officers by the Australian ballot system, such officers shall be elected in that manner until the municipality votes to discontinue use of the system.
  3. Budgets.
    1. A vote on whether to use the Australian ballot system to establish the budget shall be in substantially the following form:
    2. If a budget voted on by Australian ballot is rejected, the legislative body shall prepare a revised budget.
      1. The legislative body shall establish a date for the vote on the revised budget and shall take appropriate steps to warn a public informational meeting on the budget and the vote. The date of the public informational meeting shall be at least five days following the public notice. The date of the vote shall be at least seven days following the public notice.
      2. The vote on the revised budget shall be by Australian ballot and shall take place in the same locations that the first vote was taken; provided, however, that if that polling place is unavailable, the vote may be held at a different location, with notice posted of the meeting location at the original location.
      3. The budget shall be established if a majority of all votes cast are in favor. If the revised budget is rejected, the legislative body shall repeat the procedure in this subsection until a budget is adopted.
      4. Once a municipality votes to establish its budget by the Australian ballot system, the vote on the budget shall be taken by Australian ballot until the municipality votes to discontinue use of the system.
  4. Public questions.
    1. A vote on whether to use the Australian ballot on public questions other than the budget shall be in substantially the following form:
    2. Once a municipality has voted to vote on any specific or all public questions by Australian ballot, the votes shall be taken by Australian ballot until the municipality votes to discontinue use of the system.
  5. Use. A municipality shall not use the Australian ballot system at the same election at which its voters decide that the system shall be used.
  6. Presiding officer. The presiding officer for any election or part of an election using the Australian ballot system shall be the town clerk or as otherwise provided in section 2452 of this title.
  7. Early and absentee voting. At the time the Australian ballots are available, which shall be not less than 20 days before the election, early and absentee voting shall be permitted in accordance with chapter 51, subchapter 6 of this title.
    1. The legislative body of a town, city, or village may vote to mail a ballot to all active registered voters in the town, city, or village.
    2. A school board may, after receiving the approval of the legislative body of each member town in the district, vote to mail its annual meeting ballot to all active registered voters in the district. In such case, the town clerk and election officials in the member towns shall be responsible for the mailing of the ballots but all costs associated with the mailing of ballots shall be borne by the school district.
    3. Ballots shall be mailed not less than 20 days before the election, or as soon as they are available.
    4. The mailing of ballots shall be conducted to the extent practicable in accordance with chapter 51, subchapter 6 of this title.

"Shall (name of municipality) adopt its (name of individual budget article) or (all budget articles) by Australian ballot?"

"Shall (name of municipality) vote on (specify the public question) by Australian ballot?"

or

"Shall (name of municipality) vote on all public questions by Australian ballot?"

Hearing.

(1) Whenever a municipality has voted to adopt the Australian ballot system of voting on any public question or budget, except the budget revote as provided in subsection (c) of this section, the legislative body shall hold a public informational hearing on the question by posting warnings at least 10 days in advance of the hearing in at least two public places within the municipality and in the town clerk's office.

(2) (A) The hearing shall be held within the 10 days preceding the meeting at which the Australian ballot system is to be used. The legislative body shall be responsible for the administration of this hearing, including the preparation of minutes.

(B) In a town that has voted to start its annual meeting on any of the three days immediately preceding the first Tuesday in March in accordance with subsection 2640(b) of this title, the hearing under this subsection may be held in conjunction with that meeting, in which case the moderator shall preside.

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1979, No. 200 (Adj. Sess.), §§ 108, 120; 1981, No. 239 (Adj. Sess.), § 24; 1983, No. 30, § 1; 2003, No. 59, § 42; 2007, No. 121 (Adj. Sess.), § 13; 2015, No. 30, § 26, eff. May 26, 2015; 2015, No. 97 (Adj. Sess.), § 46; 2017, No. 50, § 54; 2021, No. 60, § 3, eff. June 7, 2021.

History

2002. In subsec. (d) of this section, added subdiv. designations (1) and (2) to conform section to V.S.A. style.

Amendments--2021. Added subsec. (g), and redesignated former subsec. (g) as (h).

Amendments--2017. Subsec. (c): Inserted "(name of individual" preceding "budget article)" and "(all budget" preceding "articles)"in the first line of the form.

Subsec. (g): Amended generally.

Amendments--2015 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (a): Inserted "Application." at the beginning.

Subsec. (e): Inserted "Use." at the beginning.

Subsec. (f): Inserted "Presiding officer." at the beginning.

Subsec. (g): Inserted "Hearing." at the beginning, and "of this title" following "subsection 2640(c)" near the end.

Amendments--2015. Subsec. (c): Added the subdiv. designations and in subdiv. (c)(2)(B), added the second half of the sentence following "The first vote was taken".

Amendments--2007 (Adj. Sess.) Subsec. (c): Inserted "article or articles" preceding "by Australian" in the ballot question.

Subsec. (g): Inserted "or budget" following "public question" in the first sentence.

Amendments--2003. Subsec. (c): Amended generally.

Subsec. (g): Substituted "except" for "including" following "question," and added "revote as provided in subsection (c) of this section" following "budget".

Amendments--1983. Deleted "and then only to the election of any or all officers, except where the municipality votes to make them applicable to any other specified business" following "have them apply" in subsec. (a), added the subsection catchline in subsec. (b), added new subsecs. (c) and (d), redesignated former subsecs. (c) and (d) as subsecs. (e) and (f), respectively, and added subsec. (g).

Amendments--1981 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (a): Added "Unless specifically required by statute" at the beginning of the subsec.

Subsec. (c): Substituted "shall not" for "may not be required to" preceding "use the Australian ballot".

Amendments--1979 (Adj. Sess.). Subsec. (d): Amended generally.

Subsec. (e): Repealed. The former subsection related to opening and closing times of polling places.

Validity of Australian ballot votes. 1981, No. 239 (Adj. Sess.), § 41, eff. May 4, 1982, provided: "The validity of a vote taken by Australian ballot prior to the effective date of this act shall not be subject to challenge for failure to comply with the procedural requirements of section 2680 of Title 17."

ANNOTATIONS

Analysis

  • 1.Generally.
  • 2.Construction.
  • 3.Manner of budget presentation.
1. Generally.

The Australian ballot is one on which the names of all candidates, or all issues, are printed, is distributed at the polling places only, and is marked in secret; though almost any written or printed ballot will suffice as long as the voter's privacy is assured. 1970-72 Op. Atty. Gen. 288. (Decided under prior law.)

2. Construction.

In this section's provision that the ballot shall not be used in municipal meetings where the population is under eight thousand unless the municipality, at its annual meeting or at a special meeting called for that purpose, votes to have it applied, and then only to the election of officers, except when such municipality shall vote to make it apply to other specified business, the phrase "called for that purpose" qualifies both "the election of officers" and "other specified business"; therefore, the meeting must be warned on the question of the ballot both when officers are to be elected and also for any other specific business. 1970-72 Op. Atty. Gen. 288. (Decided under prior law.)

3. Manner of budget presentation.

Plaintiff's claims that his rights were violated when defendant town refused to warn a decomposed, i.e., line-item, budget for approval by Australian ballot for the town meeting, as was mandated by a majority vote of town residents at an earlier special meeting, were without legal basis, and the town was justified in refusing to conduct the vote in that manner as the Legislature has given town selectboards the authority to conduct the annual budget vote by Australian ballot only if town voters approve an article in substantial compliance with the language of 17 V.S.A. § 2680(c), which allows for a vote on a complete budget. Mooney v. Town of Stowe, 183 Vt. 600, 950 A.2d 1198 (mem.) (2008).

To the extent that town voters have a right to approve the annual budget by Australian ballot, it is conferred by statute and, to exercise that right, voters must be in compliance therewith. Mooney v. Town of Stowe, 183 Vt. 600, 950 A.2d 1198 (mem.) (2008).

Cited. Pominville v. Addison Central Supervisory Union, 154 Vt. 299, 575 A.2d 196 (1990).

§ 2681. Nominations; petitions; consents.

      1. Nominations of the municipal officers shall be by petition. The petition shall be filed with the municipal clerk, together with the endorsement, if any, of any party or parties in accordance with the provisions of this title, not later than 5:00 p.m. on the sixth Monday preceding the day of the election, which shall be the filing deadline. (a) (1) (A) Nominations of the municipal officers shall be by petition. The petition shall be filed with the municipal clerk, together with the endorsement, if any, of any party or parties in accordance with the provisions of this title, not later than 5:00 p.m. on the sixth Monday preceding the day of the election, which shall be the filing deadline.
      2. A candidate shall be registered to vote in the town he or she is seeking office at or before the time of filing the petition.
    2. The candidate shall also file a written consent to the printing of the candidate's name on the ballot on or before the filing deadline for petitions as set forth in subdivision (1) of this subsection.
    3. A petition shall contain the name of only one candidate.
  2. A petition shall contain at least 30 valid signatures of voters of the municipality or one percent of the legal voters of the municipality, whichever is less. The candidate, prior to circulating his or her petitions, shall print on them his or her name as it appears on the voter checklist and shall indicate clearly on them which office he or she is seeking. If there are different lengths of term available for an office, the candidate must indicate clearly the length of term, as well.
  3. The town clerk shall make petition forms and consent forms available. Petition forms shall be sufficient if they are in substantially the following form:
  4. A person consenting to be nominated may withdraw by notifying the municipal clerk in writing no later than 5:00 p.m. on the Wednesday after the filing deadline.
  5. The officer receiving the petitions shall immediately proceed to examine them to ascertain whether they conform to the provisions of this subchapter. If found not to conform, he or she shall state in writing on the petition why it cannot be accepted, and within 24 hours from receipt he or she shall return it to the candidate in whose behalf it was filed. In this case, supplementary petitions may be filed not later than 5:00 p.m. on the Wednesday after the filing deadline. However, supplementary petitions shall not be accepted if petitions with signatures of different persons totaling at least the number specified in subsection (b) of this section were not filed by the filing deadline set forth in subdivision (a)(1) of this section.

STATE OF VERMONT

.................... County
The undersigned hereby petition the town clerk and other town officers of the Town of ...................., County of ...................., Vermont that
....................
(Name of Candidate -- Nominee)
be a nominee for election to the office of
....................
(Name of Office)
at the local election to be held in the town on the ................. day of ...................., 20 ................ We certify that we are presently voters of that town.
NAME/SIGNATURE STREET ADDRESS
..............................................................................
..............................................................................

..............................................................................
..............................................................................
..............................................................................
..............................................................................
..............................................................................

Added 1977, No. 269 (Adj. Sess.), § 1; amended 1979, No. 200 (Adj. Sess.), §§ 109, 120; 1981, No. 239 (Adj. Sess.), § 25; 1985, No. 137 (Adj. Sess.), § 3; 2013, No. 161 (Adj. Sess.), § 51; 2015, No. 30, § 27, eff. May 26, 2015; 2017, No. 50, § 55; 2019, No. 67, § 20.

History

2002. In the form in subsec. (c), substituted "20____" for "19____" to correct an outdated reference to a year in the future.

Amendments--2019. Subdiv. (a)(3): Deleted "and the candidate's name shall appear on the petition as it does on the voter checklist" following "one candidate" and deleted the second sentence.

Amendments--2017. Subdiv. (a)(1)(A): Substituted "no" for "not" following "provisions of this title" in the second sentence.

Amendments--2015. Subdiv. (a)(1): Added the subdiv. (A) designation and subdiv. (B).

Subsec. (e): Added "set forth in subdivision (a)(1) of this section" following "filing deadline" in the last sentence.

Amendments--2013 (Adj. Sess.). Section heading: Substituted "; petitions; consents" for ", petitions" at the end.

Subdiv. (a)(2): Substituted "on or before the filing deadline for petitions as set forth in subdivision (1) of this subsection" for ", no later than 5:00 p.m. on the Wednesday after the filing deadline" at the end.
